revision.comment: Rescuing 9 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{infobox civil conflict |title = 12 May Karachi violence |partof = |image = |caption = |date = 12 May 2007 |place = [[Karachi]], [[Pakistan]] |coordinates = |causes = Violent protests between pro-government activists and supporters of recently suspended [[Chief Justice of Pakistan|chief justice]] [[Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry]] |goals = |methods = [[Riot|Political]] and [[ethnic violence|ethnic riots]] |status = |result = |side1 = {{plainlist| * [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] * [[Awami National Party]] * [[Pashtunkhwa Milli Awami Party]]}} |side2 = {{plainlist| * [[Muttahida Qaumi Movement]]}} |leadfigures1 = {{plainlist| * [[Benazir Bhutto]] * [[Asfandyar Wali Khan]]}} |leadfigures2 = {{plainlist|[[Altaf Hussain (Pakistani politician)|Altaf Hussain]]}} |howmany1 = |howmany2 = |casualties1 = |casualties2 = |injuries = |fatalities = 48<ref name="accurate_fatalities" /> |arrests = [[Waseem Akhtar]] |casualties_label = |notes = }}
The '''12 May Karachi violence''', also known as '''Black Saturday riots''', were a series of violent clashes between rival political activists in [[Karachi]].<ref name="forbes">{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2007/05/14/ap3719116.html |title=Opposition to Pakistani president grows |first=Stephen |last=Graham |work=[[Forbes]] |date=13 May 2007 |accessdate=14 May 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070516061411/http://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2007/05/14/ap3719116.html |archivedate=16 May 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> The unrest began as the recently suspended [[Chief Justice of Pakistan|chief justice]] [[Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry]] arrived at the [[Jinnah International Airport]] on 12 May 2007. Gunfights and clashes erupted across the provincial capital as [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] (PPP) , [[Awami National Party]] (ANP), and [[Pashtunkhwa Milli Awami Party]] (PMAP) activists, who supported the judge, and the pro-government [[Muttahida Qaumi Movement]] (MQM) activists took to the streets against each other. Government machinery was used to block all major roads. Police was accomplice and a silent spectator to the violence. News media was attacked at Guru mandir (Business Recorder Road) when MQM activists began firing at AAJ TV headquarters which was shown on live television.<ref name="deserted">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/13/world/asia/13iht-pakistan.5.5692979.html?_r=0 |title=Riots in Karachi leave dozens dead |author=[[The Associated Press]] |date=13 May 2007 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref>
Chaudhry's supporters had announced a public rally to welcome the judge while at the same time, the MQM also announced a demonstration of their own to protest against the politicisation of the issue of judge's suspension. The MQM made plans to deliberately converge at the mausoleum of [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]] where the chief justice was to make an appearance to address a lawyers' convention and a bar association meeting<ref name="cnn">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/asiapcf/05/12/pakistan.strife/index.html |title=Deadly violence erupts in Pakistan |author=Syed Mohsin Naqvi |publisher=CNN |date=12 May 2007 |accessdate=12 May 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070513020239/http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/asiapcf/05/12/pakistan.strife/index.html |archivedate=13 May 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> at the 50th anniversary of the [[Sindh High Court|Sindh High Court Bar Association]].<ref name="ClashesMausoleum">{{cite news |url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/003200705121470.htm |author=Associated Press |title=Three shot dead in clashes in Pakistan |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=12 May 2007 |accessdate=15 May 2007 |location=Chennai, India}}</ref>
Before the citywide riots escalated, several roads were cordoned off and all routes to the airport were blocked to avoid clashes between groups. In the carnage that ensued, armed groups did a lot of carnage, cars were burnt and buildings smashed into while the ensuing gunfights left more than 40 people killed with several hundred injured and arrested. The violence continued for several days, culminating in events that led to the historic [[Lawyers' Movement]].
Several lawmakers and analysts have since questioned the incompetence of the city's security apparatus on the day of the riots and the complicity of MQM in giving rise to the riots.<ref name="accurate_fatalities">{{cite web |author=Noorilhuda |url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/opinion/06-Jun-2014/karachi-s-independence-day |title=Karachi's independence day |date=6 June 2014 |work=[[Daily Times (Pakistan)|Daily Times]] |accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref> The MQM officially denied starting the chaos and blamed it on the PPP, ANP, PMAP, Punjabi Pakhtun Ittehad (PPI) and [[Pakistan Muslim League (N)]] (PML-N) activists.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mqm.org/english-news/may-2007/mqm-rally-120507.htm |title=MQM Rally 12 May 2007 |date=12 May 2007 |type=Press release |publisher=[[Muttahida Qaumi Movement]] |accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref>
==Background== {{main|Suspension of Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry}} [[File:US Navy 051015-N-8796S-072 Pakistani President Gen. Pervez Musharraf speaks during a press conference at the Pakistan Air Force base in Chaklala Pakistan.jpg|thumb|300px|Iftikhar Chaudhry was widely expected to try and insist Musharraf (above) stand down as army chief.<ref name="chaudhry_special_aljazeera">{{cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia/2009/03/2009316513081197.html |title=Why Pakistan cares about Chaudhry |date=16 March 2009 |work=[[Aljazeera]] |accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref> The judge had also taken on several other cases that upset the government for which he was suspended from his post as chief justice.]] In the first few months of 2007, several conflicts had already raged between [[Chief Justice of Pakistan|chief justice]] [[Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry]] and the [[Government of Pakistan|Pakistani government]], particularly with regard to the [[Pakistan Steel Mills]] corruption case where the chief justice ruled against the sale of the state-owned steel mills at a "throw-away price".<ref>{{cite web |first = Mohammad |last = Kamran |url = http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/21-Jun-2006/pakistan-steel-mills-privatisation-case-ag-requests-supreme-court-to-deliver-moderate-verdict |title = Pakistan Steel Mills’ privatisation case: AG requests Supreme Court to deliver moderate verdict |work = [[Daily Times (Pakistan)|Daily Times]] |date = 21 June 2006 |accessdate = 25 June 2014 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140715200650/http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/21-Jun-2006/pakistan-steel-mills-privatisation-case-ag-requests-supreme-court-to-deliver-moderate-verdict |archive-date = 15 July 2014 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first = Shahid |last = Husain |url = http://www.downtoearth.org.in/full6.asp?foldername=20070430&filename=news&sec_id=4&sid=8 |title = Pakistan president suspends chief justice |date = March 2007 |accessdate = 13 May 2007 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928003312/http://www.downtoearth.org.in/full6.asp?foldername=20070430&filename=news&sec_id=4&sid=8 |archive-date = 28 September 2007 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Issues pertaining to the privatisation of the state-owned steel mills upset [[Shaukat Aziz]], who served as the [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|prime minister]] under the Musharraf administration.<ref name="chaudhry_special_aljazeera" />
What irked [[President of Pakistan|president]] [[Pervez Musharraf]] however was the controversial [[Missing persons (Pakistan)|Missing Persons case]] that found Pakistan's intelligence agencies (including the [[Federal Investigation Agency|FIA]]<ref>{{cite news |first = Mohammad |last = Kamran |url = http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/21-Aug-2007/missing-persons-case-produce-detainee-or-face-jail-sc-tells-fia-chief |title = Missing persons case: Produce detainee or face jail, SC tells FIA chief |date = 21 August 2007 |work = [[Daily Times (Pakistan)|Daily Times]] |accessdate = 28 June 2014 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140715021812/http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/21-Aug-2007/missing-persons-case-produce-detainee-or-face-jail-sc-tells-fia-chief |archive-date = 15 July 2014 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> and the [[Inter-Services Intelligence|ISI]]) to be complicit in the [[forced disappearance]]s<ref name="masood">{{cite news |first=Salman |last=Masood |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/13/world/asia/13cnd-pakistan.html?hp |date=13 May 2007 |title=Pakistani Leader Assailed for Deadly Clashes |work=The New York Times |accessdate=14 May 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref> of up to 400 people (including terror suspects and human rights activists) without due process since 2001.<ref name="lahore">{{cite news |first=Salman |last=Masood |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/07/world/asia/07pakistan.html?ex=1336190400&en=03eee5c48dbf6667&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss |date=7 May 2007 |title=Throngs Attend Speech by Pakistan’s Suspended Justice |work=The New York Times |accessdate=15 May 2007}}</ref> Under Chaudhry's leadership, the courts had increasingly started "exercising independence from the government"<ref name="lahore" /> when it ordered the security agencies to produce the missing people in court.<ref name="chaudhry_special_aljazeera" />
When the Musharraf administration asked the judge to quit, Chaudhry refused to go.<ref name="chaudhry_special_aljazeera" /> On 9 March 2007, Musharraf had no other choice but to suspend Chaudhry from his post for alleged and unspecified charges of misconduct and misuse of authority.<ref name="judge_sacked">{{cite news|first=Isambard|last=Wilkinson|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/1545843/Crisis-for-Musharraf-over-justice-chiefs-sacking.html|title=Crisis for Musharraf over justice chief's sacking|date=17 March 2007|location=[[Islamabad]]|work=[[Telegraph Media Group|The Telegraph]]|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> The sacking of the head of the judiciary sparked bloody protests throughout [[Pakistan]] and "edged the country towards a constitutional crisis".<ref name="judge_sacked" /> The civil unrest grew with regards to the validity of the allegations as well as doubts as to whether Musharraf had the power to suspend the chief justice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyindia.com/show/140656.php/Suspended-Pak-CJ-arrives-in-Karachi-amid-violence-and-tight-security|publisher=Daily India|title=Suspended Pak CJ arrives in Karachi amid violence and tight security|date=12 May 2007|accessdate=12 May 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927201642/http://www.dailyindia.com/show/140656.php/Suspended-Pak-CJ-arrives-in-Karachi-amid-violence-and-tight-security|archive-date=27 September 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It was on these grounds that Chaudhry waged a legal battle in the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan|Supreme Court]] seeking his reinstatement. He called his suspension a "thinly veiled assault on the independence of judiciary in Pakistan".<ref>{{cite news|first=Barbara|last=Plett|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/player/nol/newsid_6620000/newsid_6629200/6629227.stm?bw=bb&mp=wm&news=1&ms3=6&ms_javascript=true&bbcws=2|title=Lahore welcomes ousted judge|type=Video|date=6 May 2007|work=BBC World News|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref>
===Nationwide protests and media ban=== On 5 May 2007, in showing solidarity with the former chief justice, a motorcade of Chaudhry's supporters rode with him from [[Islamabad]] to [[Lahore]] where he was expected to speak at the [[Lahore High Court|Lahore High Court Bar Association]] when this motorcade of over 2,000 vehicles was stopped by the police with [[Baton (law enforcement)|baton charges]] and [[tear gas]] shelling.<ref name="support_rally_isl2lhr">{{cite news |url=http://www.dawn.com/news/245687/massive-show-of-support-for-cj |title=Massive show of support for CJ |date=6 May 2007 |work=Dawn |accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref> Debates concerning the day's events started being covered and discussed on the Pakistani news media.
The government wanted to limit the media coverage of Chaudhry's rallies and asked the Supreme Court to warn news networks that any "media coverage, discussion and analysis" that impeded legal procedures would be treated as [[contempt of court]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/245698/it|title=It’s a purely judicial issue, says president|date=6 May 2007|work=Dawn|accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref> The court issued a statement in which it said the news media, and in particular [[Geo TV]] host [[Kamran Khan (journalist)|Kamran Khan]], had broadcast "sensational reporting aimed at scandalising and maligning the honourable judges of the Supreme Court". Khan defended his actions by saying he had no malicious intent.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/asiapcf/05/09/pakistan.judicial/index.html|title=Pakistan media ban over judge battle|date=9 May 2007|work=[[CNN]]|accessdate=28 June 2014}}</ref> But when discussions of the Chaudhry's rallies persisted on television, the government decided to take drastic measures and abruptly pulled Geo TV and [[Aaj TV]] off air.
It wasn't until 9 May 2007 that the Pakistani government imposed a complete ban on the media from discussing the suspension of Chaudhry by Musharraf. Media outlets and journalists protested and responded to the ban saying that their goal was to cover, not contribute, to the controversy. The government, reluctantly, agreed to issue special passes for reporters and lawyers to attend the presidential reference filed against the chief justice.<ref name="cnn"/> Several pro-government parties throughout Pakistan announced their own demonstrations to coincide with Chaudhry's rallies.
===Chaudhry's visit to Lahore High Court=== {{quote box|width=246px|bgcolor=#ACE1AF|align=right|quote="Nations and states which are based on dictatorship instead of the supremacy of the constitution, the rule of law and protection of basic rights get destroyed."|salign=right|source=— Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, Lahore High Court, 6 May 2007.<ref name="bbc_lhc_speech">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/6629287.stm|title=Pakistan judge blasts 'dictators'|date=6 May 2007|work=BBC News|accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref>}} In anticipation of the former chief justice's arrival in Lahore, the Lahore High Court was thronged by political activists of several political parties in the opposition including [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] (PPP), [[Pakistan Muslim League (N)]] (PML-N), [[Muttahida Majlis-e-Amal]] (MMA) and [[Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf]] (PTI), who had gathered to welcome the judge. When Chaudhry did arrive at the Lahore High Court, his motorcade was swamped by supporters showering his vehicle with rose petals and chanting "Go Musharraf, Go!"<ref name="bbc_lhc_speech" /> Banners denouncing Musharraf were hung all around the compound.<ref name="lahore"/>
In his historical speech on 6 May 2007, the former chief justice made no direct references to president Musharraf but directed his rhetoric towards the government by calling it a "dictatorship".<ref name="bbc_lhc_speech" /> Several political commentators refer to this speech as the precursor to the [[Lawyers' Movement]] later that year. Chaudhry also accused the government of violating the basic human rights of its citizens and warned that the countries and nations that don't learn from past mistakes were bound to be destroyed.<ref name="lahore"/> In closing his speech, Chaudhry announced he would be attending a [[Sindh High Court|Sindh High Court Bar Association]] meeting in [[Karachi]] on 12 May 2007.
===Opposition plans to welcome Chaudhry=== After Chaudhry announced his plans for Karachi, the political parties in the opposition announced a rally to welcome the former chief justice in their city. Upon seeing Chaudhry's supporters announce a rally to welcome the chief justice, the pro-government [[Muttahida Qaumi Movement]] (MQM) organised a [[Demonstration (protest)|protest demonstration]] of their own against the "politicisation of the issue [of the justice's suspension]".<ref name="rival_protests">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/246640/karachi-braces-for-show-of-strength-by-rivals|title=Karachi braces for show of strength by rivals|date=11 May 2007|work=Dawn|accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref>
Seeing the chief justice's determination to visit Karachi, MQM MNA Nawab Mirza proclaimed in a parliamentary session that "no one [would] be allowed to do anything in Karachi." He said that "[the] country [may belong] to everyone, but Karachi [belonged] to [the MQM]". The provincial government called a meeting of the senior officials and instructed them to not let the chief justice leave the airport at any cost. Sindh chief secretary Shakil Durrani learnt of these plans and called them a "contempt of the High Court's orders".<ref>{{cite news|first=Massoud|last=Ansari|url=http://www.newslinemagazine.com/2007/06/the-day-karachi-bled/|title=The Day Karachi Bled|date=12 June 2007|work=Newsline Pakistan|accessdate=3 July 2007}}</ref>
On 10 May 2007, Pakistan International Human Rights Organisation filed a petition with the Sindh High Court pointing out reports in the press about Sindh home secretary Ghulam M. Muhtaram Naqvi's letter to the chief justice that requested him to postpone his visit because of intelligence reports suggesting threat of a terrorist attack.<ref name="shc_directs_authorities">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/246659/shc-directs-govt-to-ensure-security|title=SHC directs govt to ensure security|date=12 May 2007|work=Dawn|accessdate=1 July 2007}}</ref> The court directed the federal and provincial governments to provide fool-proof security to the chief justice and also directed authorities not to pressurise him into changing his route while also keeping him informed of any security risks.<ref name="shc_directs_authorities" />
===Unrest before Chaudhry's visit=== At {{nowrap|3 am}} on 10 May 2007, the residence of the Supreme Court Bar Association president [[Munir A. Malik]] came under attack by armed men. Malik, a member of the panel of lawyers defending Chaudhry, narrowly escaped the attack.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/246493/gunmen-attack-malik|title=Gunmen attack Malik’s house|date=11 May 2007|work=Dawn|accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref> On 11 May 2007, Karachi Bar Association vice president Ziauddin Sardar was reported missing by his family. Following these incidents, uncertainty and fear gripped the city as the "threat of a showdown loomed large".<ref name="rival_protests" />
Karachi Police informed it had arrested 150 people under the Maintenance of Public Order Ordinance on apprehensions they could "create problems" on the judge's arrival. However, opposition parties disputed the number of arrests – MMA put the figure at 500, PPP at 400 and PML-N at 150.<ref name="rival_protests" />
==The day of the riots== Fearing a showdown between rival political parties, the transporters in the city decided to keep their buses and vans off the road. In a late-night announcement,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/246657/public-holiday|title=Public holiday|date=12 May 2007|work=Dawn|accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref> the [[Government of Sindh|Sindh government]] announced the closure of all educational institutions as [[Governor of Sindh|governor]] [[Ishrat-ul-Ibad Khan|Dr Ishrat-ul-Ibad Khan]] declared a public holiday for government and private schools, colleges and universities on 12 May 2007.<ref name="rival_protests" /> Hospitals declared emergency and ordered their doctors and staff to remain on duty, while [[Naib Nazim]]a [[Nasreen Jalil]] directed all city departments including hospitals and fire-brigade to follow "[[standard operating procedure]]" to deal with any emergency situation that arises.<ref name="rival_protests" />
===City-wide blockades set up=== [[File:Karachi streets deserted on 12 May 2007.jpg|thumb|300px|Streets throughout Karachi were left deserted on the day the riots broke out bringing the provincial capital to a halt.]] Reports started emerging from around Karachi of blockades being set up on the way toward the [[Jinnah International Airport]] in a bid to stop the chief justice from visiting [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah|Muhammad Ali Jinnah's]] [[Mazar-e-Quaid|mausoleum]].<ref name="sh_quaideen_blocked">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/246651/cj-route-decision-today-malik|title=CJ route decision today: Malik|date=12 May 2007|work=Dawn|accessdate=29 June 2007}}</ref> Parts of Shahrah-e-Quaideen were blocked<ref name="sh_quaideen_blocked" /> whereas the main arterial road [[Shahrah-e-Faisal]], which was to be used by procession of the chief justice, was completely made inaccessible.<ref name="20070512_events">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/246766/riots-disrupt-karachi-calm|title=Riots disrupt Karachi calm: 34 killed, 140 injured; rivals trade allegations|date=13 May 2007|work=Dawn|accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref>
Because most of the road leading to the airport were closed, the [[Pakistan International Airlines]] (PIA) had to delay all its flight due to the non-availability of cockpit and cabin crews who were unable to reach the airport in time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/13-May-2007/pia-flights-from-karachi-disrupted|title=PIA flights from Karachi disrupted|work=Daily Times|date=13 May 2007|accessdate=30 June 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304001432/http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/13-May-2007/pia-flights-from-karachi-disrupted#|archive-date=4 March 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It wasn't just air traffic that was suspended but train services between Karachi and the rest of the country were also effected.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/13-May-2007/trains-suspended-for-six-hours|title=Trains suspended for six hours|work=Daily Times|date=13 May 2007|accessdate=30 June 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304002117/http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/13-May-2007/trains-suspended-for-six-hours#|archive-date=4 March 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Chaudhry's arrival in Karachi=== At {{nowrap|10 am}}, Chaudhry left [[Benazir Bhutto International Airport|Islamabad airport]] on flight PK-301 for Karachi accompanied by Zamurad Khan and Yousuf Talpur. The flight landed at the Jinnah International Airport in Karachi airport at {{nowrap|11:50 am}}.<ref name="chaudhry_flight">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/246616/cj-s-plane-to-take-off-for-karachi-at-10am|title=CJ’s plane to take off for Karachi at 10am|date=13 May 2007|work=Dawn|accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref>
Gunfights broke out throughout the city as soon as the plane landed at the airport; several vehicles were also set ablaze. Smoke rose from at least four different areas of the city where competing rallies were organised.<ref name="deserted" />
The chief justice had plans to visit Pakistan founder Muhammad Ali Jinnah's mausoleum to address a gathering and then to the Sindh High Court to address lawyers at the 50th anniversary of the Sindh High Court Bar Association. Due to the sudden violence that erupted throughout the city, the chief justice was unable to leave the airport.<ref name="deserted" />
===Media offices attacked=== As the violence escalated, gunfights moved toward the Guru Mandir Square in the neighbourhood of [[Jamshed Quarters]]. The offices of various media outlets, in particular the [[Business Recorder|Business Recorder House]] which housed the Aaj TV newsroom and broadcast operations, became firsthand witnesses of the carnage. With the violence continuing right at their doorstep, Aaj TV reporters began telecasting live footage of the mayhem.<ref name="aaj_attacks">{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/246780/armed-men-attack-aaj-tv-office|title=Armed men attack Aaj TV office|work=Dawn|date=12 May 2007| accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref>
The Aaj TV footage showed armed men brandishing weapons that they fired indiscriminately at rivals in an adjacent neighbourhood. The footage clearly showed these gunmen hoisting MQM flags. As soon as the footage started airing on television, the gunmen became aware they were being filmed and turned their guns towards the media offices.<ref name="aaj_attacks" /> The armed men fired at the office building and set cars ablaze in the parking lot beside the building.
The network's chief executive Arshad Zuberi later revealed that the gunmen were certainly affiliated with the MQM.<ref name="aaj_attacks" /> He stated that the "gunmen started [firing] indiscriminately at [the] office [and] no security was sent [even] though the firing went on for six hours". According to Zuberi, the armed men had wanted to stop the airing of the live footage.<ref name="ibn"/> Nevertheless, the network remained on air uninterrupted and no one was hurt during the attacks.<ref name="aaj_attacks" />
In an editorial for the [[Daily Times (Pakistan)|Daily Times]], freelance journalist Urooj Zia wrote an eyewitness account of the carnage outside the Business Recorder House. She observed how the [[Pakistan Rangers|Rangers]] paramilitary force had let the violence continue under their noses. She mentioned how people were being stopped at gunpoint on the street by political activists and asked for identification while the police stood by idly.<ref name="urooj_zia_eyewitness">{{cite news|first=Urooj|last=Zia|url=http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/karachi/14-May-2007/a-tt-to-my-forehead-and-a-press-pass-in-my-pocket|title=A TT to my forehead and a press pass in my pocket|date=14 May 2007|work=Daily Times|accessdate=1 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715070412/http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/karachi/14-May-2007/a-tt-to-my-forehead-and-a-press-pass-in-my-pocket#|archive-date=15 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Violence, carnage and mayhem=== During the rampage, it was mostly the supporters of Chaudhry who lost their lives. 15 members of [[Awami National Party]] (ANP) were killed (Pashtuns make up second largest ethnic group in Karachi with 7.0 millions pashtuns live in karachi). 14 supporters of PPP were also left dead in the massacre.<ref name="ibn">{{cite web|url=http://www.ibnlive.com/news/world/05_2007/gunmen-open-fire-at-pak-tv-channel-40437.html |title=Gunmen open fire at Pak TV channel |publisher=CNN-IBN |date=12 May 2007 |accessdate=12 May 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070514025022/http://www.ibnlive.com/news/world/05_2007/gunmen-open-fire-at-pak-tv-channel-40437.html |archivedate=14 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="PPP"/>
More than 800 political workers were arrested, majority of whom were members of labor and student organizations that had been planning to greet Chaudhry on his arrival.<ref name="cnn"/>
===Government offers to transport Chaudhry=== Unable to leave the airport, the chief justice took refuge at the airport. Knowing that roads leading up to the airport were blocked and that his leaving may further precipitate bloodshed, Chaudhry's advisers asked him to stay put. Amidst the chaos, the government agreed to send a helicopter to transport him out of the airport but Chaudhry refused, indicating that he wished to travel by ground.<ref name="cnn"/>
According to Munir A. Malik, one of the lawyers accompanying Chaudhry, Musharraf's offer to transport Chaudhry by helicopter seemed more like an attempt to "kidnap" the chief justice.<ref name="assassination"/>
===Notice to deport the chief justice=== After a whole day of violence in the city, the Sindh administration issued a notification in the evening ordering the deportation of the chief justice.<ref>{{cite news|first=Zeeshan|last=Mujahid|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/377984/may-12-mayhem-the-day-will-continue-to-haunt-the-nation/|title=May 12 mayhem: ‘The day will continue to haunt the nation’|date=13 May 2012|work=[[The Express Tribune]]|accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref> It was at this moment that Chaudhry "abandoned plans to address [his] supporters" and returned to Islamabad on the next flight. The chief justice was adamant that he would only leave the airport if he was provided with sufficient security and the accompaniment of his cadre of lawyers. Chaudhry's flight departed the Karachi airport at around {{nowrap|9 pm}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/2007/05/12/welcome.htm |title=Pakistan judge abandons rally after violence |accessdate=12 May 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070514040648/http://dawn.com/2007/05/12/welcome.htm |archivedate=14 May 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
According to [[Aitzaz Ahsan]], a prominent figurehead in Chaudhry's cadre, the chief justice had waited all day for permission to go to the Sindh High Court but was rather mistreated and asked to leave. He also accused the MQM of planning the mayhem in advance.<ref>{{cite news|first=Bakhtawar|last=Mian|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/246914/karachi-violence-was-planned-by-govt-lawyers|title=Karachi violence was planned by govt: lawyers|date=14 May 2007|work=Dawn|accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref>
==Sources of contention== [[Human Rights Watch]], a non-government affiliated human rights watch dog based in [[New York City]], recently issued a statement indicating that "This [violence] can either be due to the incompetence of the government, or its complicity."<ref name="ibn"/> Their statement went on, "The sequence of events leading up to this violence, including statements from the provincial authorities and the arrest of hundreds of opposition activists in the last few days, indicates that the government, acting through its coalition partners, has deliberately sought to foment violence in Karachi." <ref name="bloomberg">{{cite news|first=Khalid|last=Qayum|first2=Hariz|last2=Zamir|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=akyDC.kOwvik&refer=home|title=Pakistan Clashes Kill 30 in Karachi Over Top Judge|date=12 May 2007|accessdate= 12 May 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|work=Bloomberg}}</ref>
According to documents obtained by the BBC after the event, government security measures on the day of the planned demonstrations included the instruction that "no police personnel should carry any kind of weapon during the law and order duty with the rally".<ref name="bloomberg"/>
Of note, among police officials were deployed for security duties in Karachi, only 21 in the entire city were armed. BBC analysts have indicated that the way police were deployed indicates that they were meant to prevent people from gaining access to the airport or to the Sindh High Court.<ref name="PPP">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/6659137.stm |title=Karachi police told to go unarmed |author=Syed Shoaib Hasan |date=15 May 2007 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=16 May 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070518114324/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/6659137.stm |archivedate=18 May 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Aftermath== Most of the city remained calm the day following the riots as security forces in armored personnel carriers and pickup trucks with mounted machine guns patrolled mostly peaceful and deserted streets.<ref name="deserted"/> Tensions were still high with the government authorising paramilitary troops to shoot anyone involved in "serious" violence.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/asiapcf/05/13/pakistan.karachi/|title=Shoot-on-sight orders issued to end riots|date=13 May 2007|work=CNN|accessdate=2 July 2014}}</ref> Political opponents in the parliament blamed one another for the May 12 mayhem. MQM's [[Farooq Sattar]] blamed the opposition by saying that they were a "hundred percent, 200 percent" responsible for the situation in Karachi.<ref>{{cite news|first=Salman|last=Masood|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/13/world/asia/13pakistan.html?fta=y|title=At Least 27 Die as Violence Flares in Pakistan|date=13 May 2007|work=New York Times|accessdate=2 July 2014}}</ref>
On the other hand, opposition senator [[Mushahid Ullah Khan]] held the MQM responsible for the attacks in Karachi. [[National Party (Pakistan)|National Party]] senator and senior vice president [[Hasil Bizenjo]] underscored the need for an inquiry into the incidents.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/article-147475-Mushahidullah-blames-MQM-for-May-12-violence-in-Karachi|title=Mushahidullah blames MQM for May 12 violence in Karachi|date=12 May 2014|work=The News International|accessdate=2 July 2007}}</ref> An editorial in the Daily Times said, “the possibility of any compromise to correct [Musharraf's] original mistake [of removing the chief justice] has vanished now ... the ante has been upped by the government.”<ref>{{cite news|first=Salman|last=Masood|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/13/world/asia/13cnd-pakistan.html?hp|title=Pakistani Leader Assailed for Deadly Clashes|date=13 May 2007|work=New York Times|accessdate=2 July 2014}}</ref>
===Killing of Syed Hammad Raza=== {{main|Syed Hammad Raza}} At around {{nowrap|4:30 pm}} on 13 May 2007, Supreme Court additional registrar [[Syed Hammad Raza]] was shot dead near his home in Islamabad. Raza was a close associate of Chaudhry and a vital witness in the case against Chaudhry's suspension. After leaving Karachi, the chief justice visited Raza's widow Shabana the same night to present his condolences. [[Reuters]] reported Shabana telling Chaudhry, "You called him to Islamabad. You should have protected him, and now my children need protection as well.”<ref name="shabana">{{cite news|url=http://in.today.reuters.com/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=topNews&storyID=2007-05-14T214020Z_01_NOOTR_RTRJONC_0_India-298136-5.xml|title=Witness for Pakistan's suspended judge shot dead|author=Reuters|publisher=Reuters India|date=14 May 2007|accessdate=14 May 2007}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> According to Chaudhry's lawyer Tariq Mehmood, Raza was a prime witness in the case as he had witnessed the removal of files from the chief justice's chambers on the day of his suspension. He said that "[Raza] was under pressure."<ref name="shabana"/>
===Nationwide protests=== On 13 May 2007, opposition parties observed a "black day" and called for a general strike in Punjab on 14 May 2007.<ref name="opposition_strikes">{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/246916/opposition-observes|title=Opposition observes ‘black day’|date=14 May 2007|accessdate=2 July 2014}}</ref> The leaders of PPP, PML-N, MMA, PTI, ANP, PMAP, and the [[Khaksars|Khaksar Tehrik]] called for action against the miscreants that spread violence on May 12 calling them "killers".<ref>[https://www.dawn.com/news/247879 PMAP slams MQM, govt for carnage.] ''Dawn''.</ref> The Punjab leadership of the MMA held the Sindh government responsible for the loss of lives.<ref name="opposition_strikes" /> The May 14 strikes in Lahore paralysed the city as opposition activists protested against the government response to the riots. 8,000 people, including lawyers and human rights activists, chanted "Out with Musharraf!" and "Death to [[Altaf Hussain (Pakistani politician)|Altaf Hussain]]!"<ref name="assassination">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/14/world/asia/14cnd-stan.html?_r=1&hp%3Cbr%3E&oref=slogin|title=Pakistani Official Killed as Strike Called in Karachi|author=Salman Masood|date=14 May 2007|work=The New York Times| accessdate= 14 May 2007 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref> In addition, protestors burned [[effigy|effigies]] of Musharraf and hundreds forced their way through a police barricade.<ref name="forbes"/>
Authorities responded by banning demonstrations and declaring a national holiday. Shops were closed and public transportation was shut down in the country’s major cities. It is the largest strike in Pakistan since Musharraf assumed his presidency in 1999, with much of the unrest stemming from news reports that government troops were in Karachi,<ref name="assassination"/>
===Arrest of Rana Saleemullah Khan=== At a press conference on 14 May 2007, [[List of Chief Ministers of Sindh|Sindh chief minister]] [[Arbab Ghulam Rahim|Dr Arbab Ghulam Rahim]] assured that the situation in Karachi was under control and that there had been no serious incidents of violence in the days following the initial May 12 riots, despite fears to the contrary. The chief minister also indicated that opposition parties had not sought permission from the provincial government to hold their rallies on 12 May 2007. He also said the [[Pakistani general election, 2008|general elections]] would be held as scheduled in a few months and accused the opposition of showing impatience in that regard.<ref name="saleemullah_khan_arrested">{{cite news|url=http://www.aaj.tv/2007/05/situation-in-karachi-under-control-arbab/|title=Situation in Karachi under control: Arbab|date=14 May 2007|work=Aaj News|accessdate=2 July 2014}}</ref>
Rahim also revealed that the police had arrested former [[Deputy inspector general of police|DIG]] Rana Saleemullah Khan on court orders.<ref name="saleemullah_khan_arrested" /> Khan had been a vocal advocate of the chief justice and was Chaudhry's witness with regards to the Mannu Bheel case.<ref>{{cite news|first=Adeel|last=Pathan|url=http://jang.com.pk/thenews/jun2007-weekly/nos-10-06-2007/kol.htm#1|title="If I have to lose my life in the line of duty I will." – Former DIG Saleemullah Khan remains defiant|date=10 June 2007|work=[[The News International]]|accessdate=2 July 2014}}</ref> He was one of the two witnesses in that case, alongside the recently killed Syed Hammad Raza. Khan feared that his arrest was a [[facade|façade]] and a sham, and that he could become another victim of extrajudicial killing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/16-May-2007/former-dig-saleemullah-imprisoned|title=Former DIG Saleemullah imprisoned|date=16 May 2007|work=Daily Times|accessdate=2 July 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715021815/http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/16-May-2007/former-dig-saleemullah-imprisoned#|archive-date=15 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> There had been several reports that Khan was humiliated after his arrest.<ref>{{cite web|first=Abbas|last=Rashid|url=http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/editorial/02-Jun-2007/comment-a-state-of-disarray-abbas-rashid|title=Comment: A state of disarray|date=2 June 2007|work=Daily Times|accessdate=2 July 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715223748/http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/editorial/02-Jun-2007/comment-a-state-of-disarray-abbas-rashid#|archive-date=15 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Abduction of Iqbal Kazmi=== {{main|Iqbal Kazmi}} On 3 June 2007, the government announced that it would impose a ban on any televised live talk show that discusses the issue of the chief justice's suspension. It threatened to take punitive action against broadcasters that displayed an anti-state or anti-national stance and cast "aspersions on the integrity of the armed forces".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/05-Jun-2007/amended-pemra-ordinance-intolerable-ppp|title=Amended PEMRA Ordinance intolerable: PPP|date=5 June 2007|work=Daily Times|accessdate=30 June 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304003722/http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/05-Jun-2007/amended-pemra-ordinance-intolerable-ppp#|archive-date=4 March 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Under Musharraf's decree,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2007/06/05/pakistan-broadcast-media-muzzled-musharraf-s-decree|title=Pakistan: Broadcast Media Muzzled by Musharraf’s Decree|date=7 June 2007|work=[[Human Rights Watch]]|accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref> the government amended the [[Pakistan Electronic Media Regulatory Authority|PEMRA Ordinance]] to impose these new restrictions on private television channels on 4 June 2007.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/06-Jun-2007/ppp-and-pml-n-reject-amended-pemra-ord-support-journalists-protest|title=PPP and PML-N reject amended PEMRA Ord, support journalists' protest|date=6 June 2007|work=Daily Times|accessdate=30 June 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303220310/http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/06-Jun-2007/ppp-and-pml-n-reject-amended-pemra-ord-support-journalists-protest#|archive-date=3 March 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Opposition parties and lawyers campaigned against these amendments and observed a "black day" in solidarity with the broadcasters and journalists.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/07-Jun-2007/lawyers-and-journalists-to-observe-black-day-today |title = Lawyers and journalists to observe 'black day' today |date = 7 June 2007 |work = Daily Times |accessdate = 30 June 2014 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160303224412/http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/07-Jun-2007/lawyers-and-journalists-to-observe-black-day-today# |archive-date = 3 March 2016 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Amongst the petitioners was the civil rights activist [[Iqbal Kazmi|Syed Mohammad Iqbal Kazmi]] who had recently filed a petition in the Sindh High Court on the May 12 violence.<ref name="kazmi_petition">{{cite news |url=http://www.dawn.com/news/250996/ordeal-of-freed-may-12-petitioner |title=Ordeal of freed May 12 petitioner |date=9 June 2007 |work=Daily Times |accessdate=30 June 2014}}</ref>
Kazmi was abducted by unidentified persons on 6 June 2007 after he had filed his petition against the PEMRA ordinance. He was later released by his abductors on the condition that he would leave Karachi along with his family. However upon his release, Kazmi revealed that the reason for his abduction was rather his petition on the May 12 violence. He told of his harrowing ordeal where he was quizzed about his association with Imran Khan's PTI and the reasons as to why he named MQM founder and chief Altaf Hussain in his petition.<ref name="kazmi_petition" /> His petition had also included the names of several other major political and government figures as respondents alongside Hussain. The named respondents included Sindh chief minister Arbab Ghulam Rahim, [[Pakistan Ministry of Interior|federal interior secretary]] Syed Kamal Shah, adviser to Sindh CM on home affairs Waseem Akhtar, chief secretary Shakeel Durrani, home secretary Ghulam M. Muhtaram Naqvi, provincial police officer Niaz A. Siddiqui, CCPO Azhar A. Farooqui, and the [[Station House Officer|SHO]]s of City Courts and Jamshed Quarters police stations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/2007/06/09/top11.htm |title=Ordeal of freed May 12 petitioner |author=DAWN |date=14 May 2007 |work=dawn |accessdate=18 June 2007 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070611202120/http://www.dawn.com/2007/06/09/top11.htm |archivedate=11 June 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Formal inquisition== Alongside Kazmi's petition, the Sindh High Court initiated its own suo moto proceedings issuing contempt of court notices to the federal interior secretary, Sindh chief secretary and home secretary, AIGP (acting PPO), Town Police Officer and other officials who were responsible for maintaining law and order on 12 May 2007. Subsequently, the [[Human Rights Commission of Pakistan]] (HRCP) also moved an identical contempt of court application.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/karachi/18-May-2007/may-12-law-and-order-mess-shc-issues-notices-to-top-officials-for-tuesday|title=May 12 law and order mess: SHC issues notices to top officials for Tuesday|date=18 May 2007|work=Daily Times|accessdate=3 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715200700/http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/karachi/18-May-2007/may-12-law-and-order-mess-shc-issues-notices-to-top-officials-for-tuesday#|archive-date=15 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
A seven-member bench was constituted to preside over the case. The bench included justices Sarmad Jalal Osmany, Anwar Zaheer Jamali, Mushir Alam, Azizullah M. Memon, Khilji Arif Hussain, Maqbool Baqar and Ali Sain Dino Metlo, who were authorised to probe into the several issues that resulted in the May 12 bloodshed.<ref>{{cite news|first=Shujaat Ali|last=Khan|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/264384/karachi-shc-urged-to-supervise-may-12-investigation|title=KARACHI: SHC urged to supervise May 12 investigation|date=23 May 2007|work=Dawn|accessdate=3 July 2014}}</ref> [https://dnd.com.pk/12-may-karachi-violence/129171 No main culprit in this case was ever arrested]. MQM Altaf Hussian is enjoying his life in United Kingdom, former President General (retired) Musharraf is spending his time in Dubai, Europe and United States, Chief Minister Sindh Dr Arbab Ghulam Rahim went to Dubai in 2008 and came back Karachi in 2013, Governor Sindh Ishratul Ibad Khan ruled the province as Governor till 2016 and now traveling in and out of country while the then Adviser to the Sindh Chief Minister on Home Affairs Waseem Akhtar is now ruling Karachi as its Mayor.
==See also== * [[Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry]] * [[Awami National Party]] * [[Muttahida Qaumi Movement]] * [[Karachi]] * [[Pervez Musharraf]] * [[Altaf Hussain (Pakistani politician)|Altaf Hussain]] * [[Jinnah International Airport]] * [[Aaj TV|Aaj Television Network]] * [[Pakistan Peoples Party]]
==References== {{reflist|3}}
==External links== * ''[http://cjiftikharmuhammadchaudhry.blogspot.com Chief Justice Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry Blog]''
{{DEFAULTSORT:2007 Karachi Riots}} [[Category:Politics of Karachi]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Pakistan]] [[Category:2007 riots|Karachi]] [[Category:2007 in Pakistan|Karachi riots]] [[Category:Muhajir history]] [[Category:Political riots|Karachi]] [[Category:21st century in Karachi]] [[Category:History of Karachi (1947–present)]] [[Category:Ethnic riots]] [[Category:Race riots in Pakistan]] [[Category:May 2007 events]]

{{histphil}} '''17th century philosophy''' is generally regarded as seeing the start of [[modern philosophy]], and the shaking off of the medieval approach, especially [[scholasticism]]. It succeeded the [[Renaissance]] and preceded the [[Age of Enlightenment]]. It is often considered to be part of [[early modern philosophy]].
==History== The period is usually taken to start in the seventeenth century with the work of [[René Descartes]], who set much of the agenda as well as much of the methodology for those who came after him. The period is typified in Europe by the great system-builders — philosophers who present unified systems of [[epistemology]], [[metaphysics]], [[logic]], and [[ethics]], and often [[politics]] and the physical sciences too. [[Immanuel Kant]] classified his predecessors into two schools: the [[Rationalism|rationalists]] and the [[Empiricism|empiricists]],<ref>[http://www.iep.utm.edu/k/kantmeta.htm#H1 "Immanuel Kant: Metaphysics"] ([[Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy]])</ref> and [[early modern philosophy]] is often characterised in terms of a conflict between these schools.
The three main rationalists are normally taken to have been [[Descartes]], [[Baruch Spinoza]], and [[Gottfried Leibniz]]. Building upon their English predecessors [[Francis Bacon]] and [[Thomas Hobbes]], the three main empiricists were [[John Locke]], [[George Berkeley]], and [[David Hume]]. The former were distinguished by the belief that, in principle (though not in practice), all knowledge can be gained by the power of our reason alone; the latter rejected this, believing that all knowledge has to come through the senses, from experience. Thus the rationalists took [[mathematics]] as their model for knowledge, and the empiricists took the [[physical sciences]].
This period also saw the birth of some of the classics of [[political philosophy]], especially [[Thomas Hobbes]]' ''[[Leviathan (Hobbes)|Leviathan]]'', and [[John Locke]]'s ''[[Two Treatises of Government]]''.
The seventeenth century in Europe saw the culmination of the slow process of detachment of philosophy from [[theology]]. Thus, while philosophers still talked about – and even offered arguments for the existence of – a [[deity]], this was done in the service of philosophical argument and thought. (In the [[The Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]], the "Age of Reason", [[18th-century philosophy]] was to go still further, leaving theology and [[religion]] behind altogether.)
==List of seventeenth century philosophers== {{see also|List of philosophers born in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries|List of philosophers born in the seventeenth century}} * [[Francisco Suárez]] (1548–1617) * [[René Descartes]] (1596–1650) * [[Nicolas Malebranche]] (1638–1715) * [[Isaac Newton]] (1642–1727) * [[Gottfried Leibniz]] (1646–1716) * [[Pierre Bayle]] (1647–1706) * [[Damaris Cudworth Masham]] (1659–1708) * [[Mary Astell]] (1666–1731)
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Baroque literature|Philosophy]] [[Category:17th century]] [[Category:History of philosophy]]

{{Year nav topic5|1945|philosophy}}

== Events == * January 1? - [[Jean-Paul Sartre]] refuses the [[Legion of Honour]].
== Publications == * [[Aldous Huxley]], ''[[The Perennial Philosophy]]'' * [[Maurice Merleau-Ponty]], ''[[Phenomenology of Perception]]'' (''Phénoménologie de la perception'') * [[Karl Popper]], ''[[The Open Society and Its Enemies]]''
=== [[Philosophical fiction]] === * [[Hermann Broch]], ''[[The Death of Virgil]]'' (''Der Tod des Vergil'') * [[George Orwell]], ''[[Animal Farm]]'' * [[Jean-Paul Sartre]], ''[[The Age of Reason (Sartre)|The Age of Reason]]'' (''L'âge de raison'')
== Births == * September 9 - [[Robert Alexy]] * [[Philip Pettit]]
== Deaths == * February 1 - [[Johan Huizinga]] (born 1872) * April 13 - [[Ernst Cassirer]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Friedman|first=Michael|title=Ernst Cassirer|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/cassirer/|publisher=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (SEP)|accessdate=14 February 2013}}</ref> (born 1874) * June 7 - [[Kitaro Nishida]] (born 1870) * July 20 - [[Paul Valéry]] (born 1871) * December 22 - [[Otto Neurath]] (born 1882)

revision.text:
[[File:9-11 Truth 1.jpg|thumb|300px|Supporters of the 9/11 Truth movement at an anti-war demonstration in Los Angeles, October 2007]] Adherents of the '''9/11 Truth movement''' are [[conspiracy theorists]] who dispute the mainstream account of the [[September 11 attacks]] of 2001. The group disputes the commonly accepted account that [[Al-Qaeda]] terrorists hijacked four airliners, crashed them into [[the Pentagon]] and New York's [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|Twin Towers]], whereupon the crashes led to [[the collapse of the Twin Towers]]. The primary focus is on missed information that they allege is not adequately explained in the official [[National Institute of Standards and Technology|NIST]] theory, such as the collapse of [[World Trade Center 7]]. They suggest a [[Censorship|cover-up]] and, at the least, complicity by [[September 11 attacks advance-knowledge conspiracy theories|insiders]].<ref name="Feuer">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/05/us/05conspiracy.html|first=Alan|last=Feuer|title=500 Conspiracy Buffs Meet to Seek the Truth of 9/11|quote=the movement known as "9/11 Truth", a society of skeptics and scientists who believe the government was complicit in the terrorist attacks.|newspaper=New York Times|date=June 5, 2006|accessdate=May 24, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512222259/http://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/05/us/05conspiracy.html |archivedate=May 12, 2011 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Rudin">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/low/uk_news/magazine/7488159.stm|first=Mike|last=Rudin|title=The evolution of a conspiracy theory|publisher=BBC|date=July 4, 2008|accessdate=May 23, 2009}}</ref><ref name="Barber">{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/8d66e778-3128-11dd-ab22-000077b07658.html |first=Peter|last=Barber|title=The truth is out there|quote=an army of sceptics, collectively described as the 9/11 Truth movement|publisher=Financial Times|date=June 7, 2008|accessdate=May 23, 2009| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090603164130/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/8d66e778-3128-11dd-ab22-000077b07658.html |archivedate=June 3, 2009 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Powell">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/09/07/AR2006090701669_pf.html|first=Michael|last=Powell|title=The Disbelievers|quote=The loose agglomeration known as the '9/11 Truth Movement'|newspaper=Washington Post|date=September 8, 2006|accessdate=May 30, 2009}}</ref><ref name="Barry">{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/sep/10/nation/na-conspiracy10|first=Ellen|last=Barry|title=9/11 Conspiracy Theorists Gather in N.Y.|quote=... a group known as the 9/11 Truth Movement|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=September 10, 2006|accessdate=May 30, 2009| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617183636/http://articles.latimes.com/2006/sep/10/nation/na-conspiracy10|archivedate=June 17, 2009|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Hunt">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/3483477/The-30-greatest-conspiracy-theories-part-1.html|first=H.E.|last=Hunt|title=The 30 greatest conspiracy theories - part 1|quote=A large group of people - collectively called the 9/11 Truth Movement|newspaper=Daily Telegraph|location=London, UK|date=November 19, 2008|accessdate=May 30, 2009}}</ref><ref name="Kay">{{cite news|url=http://www.financialpost.com/scripts/story.html?id=f54cf9ee-4637-44de-8819-19d918b3241b&k=21893|first=Jonathan|last=Kay|title=Richard Gage: 9/11 truther extraordinaire|quote=The '9/11 Truth Movement,' as it is now commonly called|periodical=Financial Post|date=April 25, 2009|accessdate=August 4, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100701172048/http://www.financialpost.com/scripts/story.html?id=f54cf9ee-4637-44de-8819-19d918b3241b&k=21893|archivedate=July 1, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/skeptics+speak+UQAM/2976659/story.html |first=Jan |last=Ravensbergen |title=9/11 skeptics to speak at UQAM |quote=two leading voices of what's known as the 9/11 truth movement |newspaper=Montreal Gazette |date=May 2, 2010 |accessdate=May 3, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100504062139/http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/skeptics%2Bspeak%2BUQAM/2976659/story.html |archivedate=May 4, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
They analyze evidence from the attacks, discuss different [[9/11 conspiracy theories|theories]] about how the attacks happened and call for a new investigation into the attacks.<ref name="Morales">{{cite news|url=http://www.thevillager.com/villager_319/talkingpoint.html|first=Frank|last=Morales|title=9/11 Truth comes home; Pols back new investigation|periodical=Villager|date=June 11, 2009|accessdate=June 21, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090614224623/http://www.thevillager.com/villager_319/talkingpoint.html|archivedate=June 14, 2009|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Olivier"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nysun.com/news/foreign/un-official-calls-study-neocons-role-911|first=Eli|last=Lake|title=U.N. Official Calls for Study Of Neocons' Role in 9/11|newspaper=New York Sun|date=April 10, 2008|accessdate=June 21, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090529075002/http://nysun.com/news/foreign/un-official-calls-study-neocons-role-911|archivedate=May 29, 2009|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/oct2004/2004-10-29-06.asp|title=Citizens Petition New York Attorney General to Open 9-11 Inquiry|publisher=Environment News Service |date=October 29, 2004|accessdate=June 21, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thevillager.com/villager_268/pentagonpapers.html|first=Jefferson|last=Siegel|title='Pentagon Papers senator' calls for new 9/11 probe|newspaper=Villager|date=June 18, 2008|accessdate=June 21, 2009}}</ref><ref name="eastvalleytribune">{{cite news|url=http://eastvalleytribune.com/article_6294b160-5bf3-5925-b34b-856202b2f397.html|title=Sen. Karen Johnson's floor speech about 9/11|newspaper=East Valley Tribune|date=June 9, 2008 |accessdate=December 13, 2010}}</ref><ref name="Stratford Gazette"/> Some of the organizations assert that there is evidence that individuals within the [[United States government]] may have been either responsible for or knowingly complicit in the September 11 attacks. Motives suggested by the movement include the use of the attacks as a pretext to fight wars in [[Iraq War|Iraq]] and [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]] and to create opportunities to curtail American [[civil liberties]].<ref name="Rudin"/><ref name="Manjoo"/> Support for the movement is negligible from professionals in relevant fields, such as civil and aerospace engineering.<ref>''Debunking 9/11 Myths: Why Conspiracy Theories Can't Stand Up to the Facts'', by David Dunbar and Brad Reagan, Sterling Publishing Company, Inc., 2006, p.x-xix et passim</ref>
==Characteristics==
===Name=== [[File:911InsideJobSticker.jpg|thumb|Truth movement sticker]] "9/11 Truth movement" is the collective name of loosely affiliated<ref name="Manjoo">{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/ent/feature/2006/06/27/911_conspiracies |first=Farhad |last=Manjoo |title=The 9/11 deniers |publisher=Salon |date=June 27, 2006 |accessdate=September 19, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091127063119/http://www.salon.com/ent/feature/2006/06/27/911_conspiracies |archivedate=November 27, 2009 }}</ref><ref name="Bunch">{{cite news|url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/Content/Public/Articles/000/000/014/113zubvo.asp|first=Sonny|last=Bunch|title=The Truthers Are Out There|periodical=Weekly Standard|date=September 24, 2007|accessdate=September 19, 2011}}</ref> organizations and individuals that question whether the United States government, agencies of the United States or individuals within such agencies were either responsible for or purposefully complicit in the [[September 11 attacks]].<ref name="Barber"/><ref name="Powell"/><ref name="Barry"/><ref name="Hunt"/><ref name="Kay"/><ref name="Kennedy">{{cite news|url=http://www.ksl.com/?nid=148&sid=476951|first=Gene|last=Kennedy|title=BYU Professor on Paid Leave for 9-11 Theory|quote=Jones is a physics professor involved in what's called the "9-11 Truth Movement".|publisher=KSL TV|date=September 8, 2006}}</ref><ref name="Molé">{{cite journal|url=http://www.skeptic.com/eskeptic/06-09-11|first=Phil|last=Molé|title=9/11 Conspiracy Theories: The 9/11 Truth Movement Perspective|quote=a larger coalition known as the "9/11 Truth Movement"|journal=Skeptic|volume=12|issue=4|year=2006|accessdate=June 2, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090606001336/http://www.skeptic.com/eskeptic/06-09-11|archivedate=June 6, 2009 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Sales">{{cite news|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/ontheweb/features/2006/08/loosechange200608|first=Nancy Jo|last=Sales|title=Click Here for Conspiracy|quote=a nationwide collection of doubters known as the "9/11 Truth" movement|magazine=Vanity Fair|date=August 2006|accessdate=June 2, 2009 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090530062159/http://www.vanityfair.com/ontheweb/features/2006/08/loosechange200608|archivedate=May 30, 2009 |deadurl=no}}</ref> The term is also being used by the adherents of the movement,<ref name="Grossman">{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1531304,00.html|first=Lev|last=Grossman|title=Why the 9/11 Conspiracy Theories Won't Go Away|magazine=Time|date=September 3, 2006}}</ref><ref name="Harvey">{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/couriermail/story/0,23739,20341165-5007191,00.html|first=Adam|last=Harvey|title=9/11 myths Francisco Chronicle|date=September 3, 2006|accessdate=June 2, 2009}}</ref> or "9/11 Truthers",<ref name="Gravois">{{cite journal|last=Gravois|first=John|journal=The Chronicle of Higher theorists".<ref name="Bunch"/><ref name="Curiel"/> <!-- redundant from main Members of the movement are often referred to as "truthers",<ref name="Bunch"/><ref>{{cite
