{{Infobox military person | honorific_prefix = | name = Lillian Dunlap | honorific_suffix = | image = 05-7254-1 (Portraits) Lillian Dunlap, cropped.jpg | image_size = 120px | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | other_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1922|01|20}} | birth_place = [[Mission, Texas|Mission]], [[Texas]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2003|04|03|1922|01|20}} | death_place = [[Brooke Army Medical Center]]
[[San Antonio]], [[Texas]] | placeofburial = [[Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery]] | placeofburial_coordinates = | allegiance = [[United States|United States of America]] | branch = [[United States Army]] | serviceyears = 1942-1975 | serviceyears_label = | rank = [[Brigadier General (United States)|Brigadier General]] | rank_label = | servicenumber = | unit = | commands = [[United States Army Nurse Corps]] | battles_label = | battles = | awards = {{plainlist| * [[U.S. Army Distinguished Service Medal|Distinguished Service Medal]] * [[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Service Medal]] * [[Army Commendation Medal]] (1 [[Oak leaf cluster|OLC]])}} | memorials = | spouse = | relations = | children = | laterwork = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = }} '''Lillian Dunlap''' (January 20, 1922 – April 3, 2003){{cite web|last1=Sarnecky|first1=Mary T.|title=Brigadier General Lillian Dunlap: 14th Chief, Army Nurse Corps|url=https://e-anca.org/History/Superintendents-Chiefs-of-the-ANC/Brigadier-General-Lillian-Dunlap|website=Army Nurse Corps Association|accessdate=October 14, 2017}}{{cite news|title=Obituary: Lillian Dunlap|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/sanantonio/obituary.aspx?page=lifestory&pid=88833688|accessdate=October 14, 2017|work=San Antonio Express-News|date=April 6, 2003}} was an officer and [[military nurse]] in the [[United States Army]]. She served in the [[Pacific War|Pacific Theater]] during [[World War II]], later rising to the rank of Brigadier General and being made Chief of the [[United States Army Nurse Corps]]. She was decorated with the [[U.S. Army Distinguished Service Medal|Distinguished Service Medal]], the [[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Service Medal]], and the [[Army Commendation Medal]] (with [[oak leaf cluster]]).{{cite web|title=WIC Biography - Brigadier General Lillian Dunlap|url=http://www.wic.org/bio/ldunlap.htm|website=www.wic.org|accessdate=5 October 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Directors of the United States Army Nurse Corps}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dunlap, Lillian}} [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:2003 deaths]] [[Category:American nursing administrators]] [[Category:American women in World War II]] [[Category:American women nurses]] [[Category:American nurses]] [[Category:Baylor University alumni]] [[Category:Female generals of the United States Army]] [[Category:People from Mission, Texas]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Service Medal (US Army)]] [[Category:United States Army Nurse Corps officers]] [[Category:University of the Incarnate Word alumni]] [[Category:Women in war in East Asia]] [[Category:Women in warfare post-1945]] {{US-army-World-War-II-bio-stub}} {{Nurse-bio-stub}}

[[Prizren]] along with its historical values contributes to not only the city itself, but the entire territory of [[Kosovo]].{{ref label|status|a|}} Numerous data that have remained from the past suggest that this area has been inhabited since ancient times. Among the most valuable assets of Prizren are material values that are inherited from past centuries. Thanks to the suitable geographical position, Prizren is a woven together place where civilizations and different cultures meet. This list includes historical, cultural, religious and natural monuments of the municipality of Prizren, which are listed by the government of the [[Republic of Serbia]], [[Republic of Kosovo]], Municipality of Prizren, International NGOs and Local NGOs.
[[File:Ura e Gurit dhe Xhamia Sinan Pasha, Prizren.jpg|thumb|right|480px|Stone Bridge and Sinan Pasha Mosque]]
==Culture monuments==
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Number ! Name ! Description ! Location ! Photo |- | 1 | Shadervani | Shadervani is located in the center of Prizren and by many is considered as the point of activity where the cultural, economic and social development intersect. The meaning of “Shadervan” comes from Persian language which stands for “fountain with many streams”.<ref name="dem" /><ref name="exsk" /><ref name="ptv" /><ref name="ec" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.208999|20.74047|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Berat Hoxha 10.jpg|thumb|Shadervani]] |- | 2 | Fortress of Prizren | The exact date of the building of the Fortress of Prizren is not known. However, it is believed that the fortress dates from the 6th century. Through the years it has been used for habitat and military purposes. A characteristic of the fortress is the 42-stair tunnel which is located on the eastern side and takes you down to the [[Prizren Bistrica|Lumbardhi River]].<ref name="lb">Prizreni i Lashtë - Morfologjia e ecurive për ruajtjen e kulturës materiale, Muhamed Shukriu, 2001</ref><ref name="ec">[http://www.chwbkosovo.org/file.php?file=EC_Prizren.pdf Prizreni në Retrovizore] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222073155/http://www.chwbkosovo.org/file.php?file=EC_Prizren.pdf |date=2014-02-22 }}, Ec Ma Ndryshe</ref><ref name="webi">[http://www.prizren360.com/en/en/what-to-visit/monuments/ Prizren 360]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Prizren Municipality</ref><ref name="vc">Prizreni - Vendtakim i civilizimeve, Komuna e Prizren, Drejtoria për Turizëm dhe Zhvillim Ekonomik, 2012</ref><ref name="chwb">[http://www.chwbkosovo.org/file.php?file=Prizren_Conservation_and_Development_Plan.pdf Plani i Konservimit dhe zhvillimit për zonën historike të Prizrenit, Kosovë] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130826121102/http://www.chwbkosovo.org/file.php?file=Prizren_Conservation_and_Development_Plan.pdf |date=2013-08-26 }}, Cultural Heritage without Borders, 2011</ref><ref name="exsk">Explore the South of Kosovo, The Municipality of Prizren</ref><ref name="dem">Prizreni në kohën antike iliro dardane romake bizantine mesjetare osmane, Shoqata Numizmatike Shqiptare "Demastion", 2003</ref><ref name="mrjk">Monografia e Rajonit Jugor të Kosovës, Arbeiter-Samariter-Bund, 2012</ref><ref name="ptv">Prizren The Visitor, Komuna e Prizrenit, 2012</ref> | <small>{{Coord|42.209321|20.745403|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Prizren Castle - Kosovo.JPG|thumb|Prizren Castle - Kosovo]] |- | 3 | Višegrad Fortress | Medieval [[Serbia]]n Višegrad Fortress is located in the gorge of [[Prizren Bistrica]]. It was built for defensive purposes against attacks, and as a protection for [[Serbian Orthodox]] [[Monastery of the Holy Archangels]], built by Serbian Emperor [[Dušan Silni]].<ref name="dem" /><ref name="ptv" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.199124|20.763429|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Medieval Višegrad Fortress, Prizren, Serbia.jpg|thumb|Višegrad Fortress]] |- | 4 | The Complex of the League of Prizren | The Albanian League of Prizren today is a museum, where on June 10, 1878 the Assembly of Prizren was gathered to discuss the program that would consolidate Albanian leaders to unite and protect the country against foreign threats. The museum is now home to photographs, documents, objects and clothing that date from the time of the Assembly.<ref name="dem" /><ref name="exsk" /><ref name="ptv" /><ref name="ec" /><ref name="chwb" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="vc" /><ref>Muzeu i Lidhjes - Kompleksi Monumental i Lidhjes Shqiptare te Prizrenit, Instituti i mbrojtjes se monumenteve kulturore</ref><ref>Monumentet historiko-kulturore te Lidhjes Shqiptare te Prizrenit, Parim Kosova, 2004</ref><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> The League of Prizren museum was destroyed with [[Rifle grenade|rifle-propelled grenades]] by Yugoslav Serb police during the [[Kosovo War]] in March 1999.<ref name="Bevan85">{{cite book|last=Bevan|first=Robert|title=The Destruction of Memory: Architecture at War|year=2007|location=|publisher=Reaktion books|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=Xuz6GngdaVsC&pg=PT122&dq=kosovo+war+museum+prizren&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=kosovo%20war%20museum%20prizren&f=false|isbn=9781861896384|pages=85|ref=harv}} "The Memorial Museum of the League of Prizren was not destroyed by a 'NATO missile' but by Serbian police in March 1999 using rifle-propelled grenades."</ref><ref name="Armatta93">{{cite book|last=Armatta|first=Judith|title=Twilight of Impunity: The War Crimes Trial of Slobodan Milosevic|year=2010|location=Durham|publisher=Duke University Press|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=pXygFoqg-G0C&pg=PA93&dq=Kosovo+war+Catholic+churches+damaged&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Kosovo%20war%20Catholic%20churches%20damaged&f=false|isbn=9780822391791|pages=93|ref=harv}} "Riedlmayer described how investigators reached their conclusions that damage was not caused by air strikes. In the case of the Museum of the Prizren League, Riedlmayer noted several facts inconsistent with damage from NATO aerial bombardment: (1) no nearby building was damaged; (2) a hit by an explosive device would have left nothing of the mud, brick, and wood construction; (4) the museum was a monument to the Albanian national movement; (3) eyewitnesses said that Serbian police destroyed the building with handheld incendiary devices; and (5) life-sized statues of the league’s founders, in back of the museum, were found in the river after the war. All of this supported the conclusion that Serbian forces on the ground had maliciously targeted the museum."</ref> | <small>{{Coord|42.211363|20.743784|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:House of the League of Prizren.JPG|thumb|House of the League of Prizren]] |- | 5 | The Milling of Marash - Shotman | The Milling of Shotman was built in 1641 and is considered to be the oldest Milling in Prizren. Currently the Milling of Shotman serves as a restaurant which is an interesting tourism spot.<ref name="ec" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.401023|20.167251|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Mulliri i Shotmanit.JPG|thumb|Mulliri i Shotmanit]] |- | 6 | The Hammam of Gazi Mehmet Pasha | The Hammam was built in the 16th century by Mehmet Pasha. The Hammam of Gazi Mehmet Pasha is considered to be one of the biggest in the Balkans and belongs to the most successful period of Ottoman architecture. The initial role of the Hammam was to serve as a public bathroom; however, currently is used as a place for various cultural purposes.<ref name="dem" /><ref name="exsk" /><ref name="ptv" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.210779|20.741575|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Hamami - Prizren 2.jpg|thumb|Hamami - Prizren 2]] |- | 7 | Clock Tower and the Archaeological Museum | The Clock Tower was built in 1948 and served the purpose of time orientation for citizens. The Archaeological Museum was opened on November 17, 1975 where you can find over 790 archeological findings from the region of Prizren.<ref name="exsk" /><ref name="ptv" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.211268|20.736538|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Muzeu Arkeologjik dhe Sahat Kulla.JPG|thumb|Muzeu Arkeologjik dhe Sahat Kulla]] |- | 8 | Beledija | Beledija is the building where the first Municipal Assembly of Prizren was held at the end of the 19th century. Currently the building is used as an information center for cultural inheritance and for tourists’ orientation.<ref name="ec" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.210322|20.735083|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Beledija.JPG|thumb|Beledija]] |- | 9 | The Milling of Shasivar Beut | The Milling of Shasivar Beu is the only functional milling out of all millings in Prizren to this day which was built in the 19th century.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.209957|20.732841|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Mulliriii.JPG|thumb|Mulliri]] |- | 10 | The Museum of Hydro Power Plant - “Prizrenasja” | The Museum of Hydro Power Plant was built in 1929 in the gorge of [[Prizren Bistrica|Lumbardhi River]] by company from Vienne. This is especially valuable because it is the only hydro power plant in Kosovo. The Hydro Power Plant has been functional for 44 years, until November 1, 1974 and on November 8, 1979 it was transformed into a museum of electro-economics of Kosovo.<ref name="ptv" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.194637|20.772577|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Prizenasja.JPG|thumb|Prizenasja]] |- | 11 | The Shadervani Fountain | The Shadervani Fountain is one of the main symbols of the city of Prizren with four creeks which continuously provide drinking water for citizens of Prizren.<ref name="ptv" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.209015|20.740481|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Kroi i Shatervanit.JPG|thumb|Kroi i Shatervanit]] |- | 12 | The Six Fountains Topokli | The Six Fountains Topokli are located in the entrance of Marash. The exact date of the building of the Fountains is not known, however, it is believed that they belong to the period previous to Ottoman occupation.<ref name="ptv" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.211546|20.744402|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Krojet Topokli.JPG|thumb|Krojet Topokli]] |- | 13 | The Fountain of Bimbash | The date of building is not known and is supposed to have been built by an officer of the Ottoman Empire. It was of great importance for citizens who lived near-by the fountain.<ref name="ptv" /><ref name="ec" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.209516|20.736463|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Kroi i Bimbashit.JPG|thumb|Kroi i Bimbashit]] |- | 14 | The Fountain of the Mosque of Sinan Pasha | The Fountain of the Mosque of Sinan Pasha is part of the mosque which was built in the 16th century.<ref name="ptv" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.209082|20.741189|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Kroi i Sinan Pashes.JPG|thumb|Kroi i Sinan Pashes]] |- | 15 | The Stone Bridge | The Stone Bridge was built from Ali Beu in the 16th century in the oriental style and has spherical shape. In 1979 the Bridge was destroyed due to floods, and was rebuilt in 1982 which left the Bridge with some substantial changes in its architecture.<ref name="ec" /><ref name="dem" /><ref name="exsk" /><ref name="ptv" /><ref name="ec" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek">Trashegimia e evidentuar e Kosoves, Ministria e Kultures, Rinise dhe Sportit, 2005</ref> |<small>{{Coord|42.209567|20.740599|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Stone Bridge in Prizren (by Pudelek).JPG|thumb|Bridge in Prizren and the Prizrenska Bistrica]] |- | 16 | The Bridge of Arasta | The Bridge of Arasta was built in the 18th century and served as an indoor market.<ref name="ptv" /><ref name="ec" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.209571|20.741725|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Ura 13.JPG|thumb|Ura 3]] |- | 17 | The Bridge of Nalet | The Bridge of Nalet was a small bridge that was initially built from wood. The name of the Bridge means the “bridge of the devil” and it was named so because very often people who crossed the bridge slipped and fell into the river.<ref name="ptv" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.209615|20.739|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Ura e Naletit.JPG|thumb|Ura e Naletit]] |- | 18 | The Bridge of “Syzi Çelebia” - Tabakhanës | The bridge of “Syzi Celebia” known from the citizens of Prizren as the “Bridge of Tabakhane” build from Syzi Celebi in 1513, which was used to pass into the neighborhood of Tabakhane, now rebuild but still keeps its architectural values.<ref name="ptv" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.209758|20.736506|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Ura tabakhanes.JPG|thumb|Ura tabakhanes]] |- | 19 | The old Stone Bridge in Kerk Bunar | Stands outside the city which connects the region of Zhupa with the city, this bridge holds on to limestone rocks.<ref name="ptv" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.194308|20.774287|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 20 | Vlashnje | Vlashnja is one of the villages with high historical values, contains two archeological values like the one of “The Cave of Vlashnje, where in the area of the village, pictures can be found, which date prehistoric. The archeological settlement of Vlashnja is also own, which also dates since prehistoric times, furthermore in this area passed the road Lissus-Naissus, which connected the Adriatic with the Balkans.<ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="agp">Guida Arkeologjike e Prizrenit, Komuna e Prizrenit - Drejtoria e Turizmit dhe Zhvillimit Ekonomik, 2012</ref> |<small>{{Coord|42.200611|20.661114|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Vlashnja.JPG|thumb|Vlashnja]] |- | 21 | The Fortress of Koriša – The early Christian Church | The Fortress is located outside of the Koriša village, in an area which the villagers otherwise call the Fortress Hill or Gralište. The Fortress visually converses with all fortresses in the region of Prizren. Whereas the early Christian church was built in the 6th century.<ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="agp" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.257222|20.801708|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Kalaja kabashit.JPG|thumb|A panoramic view]] |- | 22 | The Hisar of Nashec | Even though the excavations have not been finished yet, it is told that this Hisar dates to Bronze times, and it has a big historical value for Prizren.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="agp" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.241958|20.651672|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Hisari i Nashecit.JPG|thumb|Hisari i Nashecit]] |- | 23 | Romaja | Romaja is a village in the region of Hasi, even in this village after archeological excavations some ceramic pots for daily use have been found, and other items such as working tools, weapons and ornaments.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="agp" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.293596|20.590947|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Romaja.JPG|thumb|Romaja]] |- | 24 | Pirana | A village in the municipality of Prizren, with high archeological values, in which “The Messenger of Pirana” has been discovered; where it is thought that it has been populated/inhabited since Roman times.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="agp" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.292866|20.671413|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 25 | Vermica | In this village archeological excavations have been going on since 1975, and life in this area is dated from the 4th to 6th centuries.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="agp" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.16423|20.570734|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 26 | Gjonaj | Gjonaj is another region which belongs to the region of Has, where archeological excavations have been made in 1978, and after the discoveries that have been made there, it is thought that this settlement belongs to the Middle Ages, the 10th to 13th centuries.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="agp" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.253617|20.622018|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 27 | The Fortress of Karashengjergjit | This Fortress rests on the place where the region of Has connects with the Pashtrik Mountain, and from the outer walls architecture it is thought that it dates back to the middle-ages.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="agp" /> |<small>{{Coord|42.265734|20.608438|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |}
==Religious monuments==
===Mosques===
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Number ! Name ! Description ! Location ! Photo |- | 1 | Namazxhahu – Kerk Mosque | One of the first monuments of Islam culture build from Isa Beu, in 1455 it served for praying. The word ‘Namazxhahu’ derives from the Persian language which means ‘prayer’.<ref name="dem" /><ref name="exsk" /><ref name="ptv" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.214089|20.730942|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Xhamia e Namazxhauhut.JPG|thumb|Xhamia e Namazxhauhut]] |- | 2 | The Mosque of Syzi Çelebisë | This mosque is the oldest mosque in the city of Prizren, build in 1513 from Suzi Celebiu which his real name was Muhamed Mahmut Abdullahu. His grave and the graves of his brothers are in the mosque yard.<ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.20969|20.734119|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Xhamia e Suzi Efendise.JPG|thumb|Xhamia e Suzi Efendise]] |- | 3 | The Mosque of Sarachan – Kuklibej | The mosque was given the name The Mosque of Sarachan since in the neighborhood where the mosque is located, it is built from belts and skins. It is one of the oldest mosques in the city build in 1534 and it was built from Kukli Mehmed-beu.<ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.210481|20.74091|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Xhamia e Kuklibeut.JPG|thumb|Xhamia e Kuklibeut]] |- | 4 | The Mosque of Gazi Mehmed Pasha | The mosque was built by Gazi Mehmed Pasha in 1573, and located in the complex of the Albanian League of Prizren. It is among the largest mosques in Prizren. Also in this part Gazi Mehmed Pasha built the madrasah, shrines, libraries etc.<ref name="dem" /><ref name="ptv" /><ref name="chwb" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.211385|20.743019|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Xhamia e Bajraklise.JPG|thumb|Xhamia e Bajraklise]] |- | 5 | The Mosque of Sinan Pasha | The Mosque which is located in the city center so near the ‘Shadervan’, built in 1615 by Sinan Pasha. The mosque was built from the stones of the Serbian Orthodox [[Monastery of the Holy Archangels]].<ref name="dem" /><ref name="exsk" /><ref name="ptv" /><ref name="chwb" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.208965|20.741251|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:SinanPasha.JPG|thumb|SinanPasha]] |- | 6 | The Mosque of Emin Pasha | The Mosque characterized by the drawings it has. Built in 1831 by Mehmet Emini.<ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.211282|20.74124|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Xhamia e Emin Pashes.JPG|thumb|Xhamia e Emin Pashes]] |- | 7 | The Mosque of Iljaz Kuka | This mosque was built by Kuklibeg in 1543, was repaired several times and in the inscription of the date of construction now is the date of refurbishing that was made by Ahmed Bey in 1897.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.209194|20.736522|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Xhamia e Ilijaz Kukes.JPG|thumb|Xhamia e Ilijaz Kukes]] |- | 8 | The Mosque of Maksut Pasha – Marashi | It was built by Maksut Pasha, presumed to have been built in the 17th century.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.212094|20.745113|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Xhamia e Maksud Pashes.JPG|thumb|Xhamia e Maksud Pashes]] |- | 9 | Mosque of Arasta or Mosque of Evrono | This mosque was built between the years 1526 and 1538 by Evrenos - Zade Jakup Bey. To this day only the minaret stands since in the year of 1911 the government of the time made the demolition of the mosque and the whole market.<ref name="exsk" /><ref name="ptv" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.210308|20.74182|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Xhamia e Arastes.JPG|thumb|Xhamia e Arastes]] |- | 10 | Mosque of Haxhi Kasemi | Was built by Haxhi Kasemi, the exact year of construction is not known but it is supposed to be built in 1526. In the inscription it shows the year 1831, when the reconstruction was done by Mahmut Pasha in honor of his mother.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.208546|20.732064|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Xhamia e Haxhi Kasemit.JPG|thumb|Xhamia e Haxhi Kasemit]] |- | 11 | Terzi Mehmet Bey Mosque | The first inscription does not exist. It is supposed to be built in 1721 by Mehmed Bey Terzi.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.208999|20.74047|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 12 | Myderiz Ali Efendi Mosque | Built in 1581 from the Myderiz of Prizren Ali Efendi.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.208288|20.737761|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:PrizrenCollection2 2010 100 2517.JPG|thumb|A panoramic view of "Lidhja e Prizrenit"]] |- | 13 | Mosque of Terxhiman Iskender | Supposedly built around the 18th century by Terxhuman Iskender.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.215362|20.74437|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Xhamia e Terxhymen Iskenderit.JPG|thumb|Xhamia e Terxhymen Iskenderit]] |- | 14 | Çatip Sinan Mosque - Ljevisha | The exact date is not known but it is assumed that the building was built before the year 1591, by the Catip "Secretary" Sinan who was the Catip of the Sultan’s archives.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.213846|20.74158|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Xhamia e Sinan Katip.JPG|thumb|Xhamia e Sinan Katip]] |}
===Churches===
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Number ! Name ! Description ! Location ! Photo |- | |[[Our Lady of Ljeviš]] |Mother of God Ljeviška is a 14th-century [[Serbian Orthodox church]] in the town of [[Prizren]]. It was converted to a [[mosque]] during the [[Ottoman Empire]] and then back into a church in the early 20th century.[[UNESCO]]-protected 14th century Serbian Orthodox monastery. The construction of the church was commissioned in 1306–9 by Serbian King [[Stefan Milutin]].<ref name="StrikerEmerick2005">{{cite book|last=Curcic|first=Slobodan|editor=Judson J. Emerick|title="Renewed from the Very Foundations": The Question of the Genesis of the Bogorodica Ljeviska in Prizren|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PyXqAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=26 November 2012|series=Archaeology in architecture: studies in honor of Cecil L. Striker|year=2005|publisher=von Zabern|isbn=9783805334921|page=23}}</ref> It was built on the site of the ruins of an earlier [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] church, whose original name ''Metera Eleousa'' was preserved in Slavic as ''Bogorodica Ljeviška''. | | [[File:Bogorodica Ljeviska1.jpg|300px]] |- | 1 | [[Monastery of the Holy Archangels]] | Monastery of the Holy Archangels is a [[Serbian Orthodox]] [[monastery]] located in [[Prizren]], founded by the Serbian Emperor [[Stefan Uroš IV Dušan of Serbia|Stefan Dušan]] (reigned 1331–1355) between 1343 and 1352 on the site of an earlier church, part of the [[Višegrad (Bistrički)|Višegrad fortress complex]]. It was the burial church for Emperor Dušan, and represented the culmination of the [[Serbian art|Serbian ecclesiastical archritectural style]], that led to the birth of the [[Morava school]] style. The complex, which ranges over 6,500 [[Square metre|m²]], includes two churches, the main one is dedicated to the Holy Archangels (where Dušan's tomb lied), and the second one is dedicated to [[St. Nicholas]], both built in the [[Rascian architecture|Rascian architectural style]], although, like the [[Visoki Dečani]] monastery, regarding time of the construction, and some architectural elements, it may belong to the [[Vardar school|Vardar architectural style]]. The monastery was looted and destroyed after the [[Ottoman Turks|Ottomans]] arrived in 1455, and in 1615 it was razed to the ground and its material was used for the construction of the [[Sinan Pasha Mosque (Prizren)|Sinan Pasha Mosque]] in Prizren.<ref name=Jovanovic-Archangels>{{harvnb|Jovanović|loc=Introduction}}</ref>
The entire complex was [[Excavation (archaeology)|archeologically explored]] in 1927, and its remains were conserved after the [[Second World War]]. During the last decade of the 20th century, work on the reconstruction was continued, and in 1998 it again became an active male monastery. After the [[1999 NATO bombing of Yugoslavia]] and retreat of the [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] army forces, reconstructed objects were burned and looted in June 1999, by members of the [[Kosovo Liberation Army]] (KLA), after the [[Kosovo Force]] (KFOR) arrived. During the [[2004 unrest in Kosovo]], the monastery was burned and looted again. The entire monastery complex is under protection of the [[Serbia|Republic of Serbia]], as a [[Monument of Culture of Great Importance]], and today in the monastery lives one priest and the monastery is under constant protection of Kosovo Police and in a special protection zone.<ref name=Kosovo.net-Archangels>{{harvnb|Kosovo.net|loc=Holy Archangels Monastery page}}</ref><ref name=Studija>{{cite journal|first1=Zoran |last1=Garić |first2=Svetlana |last2=Hadžić |url=http://www.coe.int/t/dg4/cultureheritage/Regional/SEE/IRPPSAAH/FS/FS_KosovoUNMIK_MonasteryHolyArchangels_Prizren_APP.pdf |title=Monastery of the Holy Archangels – Prizren |publisher=Council of Europe |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215201556/http://www.coe.int/t/dg4/cultureheritage/Regional/SEE/IRPPSAAH/FS/FS_KosovoUNMIK_MonasteryHolyArchangels_Prizren_APP.pdf |archivedate=February 15, 2009 }}</ref> | <small>{{Coord|42.20069|20.763542|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Erzengelkloster1.jpg|300px|Monastery of the Holy Archangels]] |- | 2 | [[Cathedral of Our Lady of Perpetual Succour, Prizren|Cathedral of Our Lady of Perpetual Succour]] | The Cathedral was built in 1870 by Archbishop Dario Bucareli. It is known for two paintings of known personalities of Balkans past, the painting of George Kastrioti - Skanderbeg, the prince of the Principality of Albania and Johannes de Hunajad, Governor and warlord of Hungary.<ref name="dem" /><ref name="ptv" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.207644|20.738409|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 3 | [[Church of the Holy Saviour, Prizren|Church of the Holy Saviour]] | This monument located near the castle belongs to the city and medieval architecture. The church was declared a [[Monuments of Culture of Exceptional Importance (Serbia)|Monument of Culture of Exceptional Importance]] in 1990, and it is protected by the [[Republic of Serbia]].<ref>[http://spomenicikulture.mi.sanu.ac.rs/spomenik.php?id=333 Споменици културе у Србији - ''Црква светог Спаса'']</ref> It was heavily damaged by a Kosovo Albanian mob during the [[2004 unrest in Kosovo]].<ref>[http://www.spc.rs/Vesti-2004/03/18-3-04_l04.html News from Kosovo and Metohija]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{sr icon}}</ref><ref name="dem" /><ref name="ptv" /><ref name="chwb" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.208105|20.743302|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Kisha 3.JPG|300px|Church of the Holy Saviour]] |- | 4 | Church of the Holy Sunday - Saint Mark | Built in 1371 by King Marko Vukasin Kraleviqi. For its architectural values already is well known for a stelle the Roman period.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.20828|20.743034|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 5 | Church of St George | Church of St. George is located in the central part of Prizren, respectively between Shatervanit. Objekti was built in the late 15th century by the brothers Runoviq. Facility Within the southwest side is the tomb of Metropolitan Mihajlo, which also frescoes dating from the XVII.<ref name="ptv" /><ref name="chwb" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.208292|20.740019|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Kisha 1.JPG|300px|Church of St George]] |- | 6 | [[Church of St. Nicholas, Prizren|Church of St. Nicholas]] | The Church of St. Nicholas, also known as '''Tutić Church''' (Tutićeva crkva) is a [[Serbian Orthodox Church|Serbian Orthodox]] [[Church (building)|church]]. It was founded in 1331-1332 by [[Dragoslav Tutić]], whose monastic name was Nikola (Nicholas), and his wife Bela. Later, the church became a possession of the [[Visoki Dečani Monastery]]. Since 1990, it has been on Serbia's list of [[Monuments of Culture of Exceptional Importance (Serbia)|Monuments of Culture of Exceptional Importance]].<ref name="SANU" >{{CHS-SANU|Link=343|Name=Crkva Svetog Nikole, Prizren}}</ref> At the time of the [[2004 unrest in Kosovo]], the church was vandalized.<ref name="vandalism">[http://www.kosovo.net/news/archive/2004/May_17/5.html Ekspertska delegacija Saveta Evropa zavrsila posetu spomenicima Kosovu did i Metohija koji su u unisteni martovskom pogromu] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501032626/http://kosovo.net/news/archive/2004/May_17/5.html |date=2011-05-01 }}, May 17, 2004, http://www.kosovo.net</ref> Since 2005, with financial support from the [[European Union]], work has been undertaken to restore the church to its original state.<ref name="RIC">[http://www.rickosovo.org/inc/eng/sites/c_st_nicholas_tutic_prizren.html Church of St Nicholas (Tutic'church)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120429174513/http://www.rickosovo.org/inc/eng/sites/c_st_nicholas_tutic_prizren.html |date=2012-04-29 }}, Prizren, http://www.rickosovo.org, Reconstruction Implementation Commission for Serbian Orthodox Religious Sites in Kosovo</ref> | <small>{{Coord|42.208284|20.739311|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Kisha 4.JPG|300px|Church of St. Nicholas]] |- | 7 | Groups of Zym | Zymi parish center was recognized as the 14th century the church was dedicated to St. Mary in lifting qiell. The first church of this village were Shëngjergj while later moved to the foothills of Lumezeve.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.272768|20.624618|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 8 | [[Hermitage of St. Peter of Koriša]] | Hermitage and Monastery of Saint Peter Koriški is a ruin of the hermitage and monastery located in [[Koriša]], [[Prizren]] The Monastery is an ancient cave dwelling that was abandoned in 1453 after the Turkish invasion.<ref name="Koriša">{{cite web|url=http://www.kosovo.net/ekorisa.html|title=Koriša|work=Monastery of St. Peter of Koriša|publisher=Serbian Orthodox diocese of Raška and Prizren|accessdate=10 December 2010}}</ref> After monastery disbandment, remains of [[St. Peter Koriški]] were moved to the [[Crna Reka Monastery]] in 1572. Hermitage of Saint Peter Koriški was declared cultural monument on 16 December 1950,<ref>Rešenje Zavoda za zaštitu i naučno proučavanje spomenika kulture NRS u Beogradu, br. 1573 od 16.12.1950.g. Zakon o zaštiti spomenika kulture i prirodnih retkosti (Sl. glasnik NRS br. 54/4).</ref> and registered as a [[Protected Monuments of Culture (Serbia)|Protected Monument of Culture]] in 1990, and it is protected by [[Republic of Serbia]].<ref>{{CHS-SANU|Link=311|Name=MANASTIR I ISPOSNICA SV. PETRA KORIŠKOG}}</ref> The construction of this church began in the end of the 11th century, and it continued until the 14th century. It is also known as “The Bad Church” because of the inconvenient location it is located in.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.251552|20.807523|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Saint Peter Koriški Hermitage.JPG|300px|Hermitage of St. Peter of Koriša]] |}
===Tekkes===
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Number ! Name ! Description ! Location ! Photo |- | 1 | Tekke of Tarikat Sinan | The Tekke of Sinan tarikat was first built in 1575 by Ummi Sinan from Prizren who at the same time is also the founder of this sect/tarikat in Kosovo. It is located in the right side of Lumbardh, respectively in the Tabak neighborhood.<ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.214073|20.746563|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 2 | Tekke of Tarikat Kaderi Zingjiri | Qadiriyyah - Zingjirli Tekke was built in 1646 by Shaykh Hasan Horosani and is located north of Prizren. The tekke qualifies as the oldest in the Balkans of this sect.<ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.214772|20.731863|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 3 | Tekke of Tarikatit Halveti | The Tekke of the Halveti tarikat was established in 1605 by Sheikh Osman Baba Tekke in the neighborhood of Saraqhan. It is the main Tekke of Prizren, while it has other branches in Rahovec, Mitrovice and Albania.<ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.210251|20.740673|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:PrizrenCollection2 2010 100 2320.JPG|thumb|PrizrenCollection2 2010 100 2320]] |- | 4 | Tekke of Tarikatit Bektashi | The Tekke of Bektashi tarikat was founded in 1850 by Adem Baba of Prizren. This Tekke is located head-to-head to the Hasan Beg Mill southwest of the city.<ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.207747|20.733345|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 5 | Tekke of Tarikatit Rufa'i | The Rufa'I Tekke was established in 1892 by Sheikh Shasan Hysni Sanxhaku. A characteristic of this masjid or tekke, is the ritual which is held on the first day of spring during which members of the sect are poked in different parts of the body.<ref name="ptv" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.211812|20.745395|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Teqja 1.JPG|thumb|A panoramic view of "Lidhja e Prizrenit"]] |- | 6 | Tekke of Dallgen Baba | Tekke of Dallgen Baba. This shrine was devoted to one of the commanders who led part of the left army of the Ottoman Empire during the invasion of Prizren in 1945.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.213254|20.731908|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 7 | Tekke of Karabash Baba | The Tekke of Karabash Baba is located in the complex of Karabash respectively near the University of Prizren. Inside the tekke there’s the tomb of a military commander of the Ottoman Empire from which it takes its name.<ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.205284|20.727293|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 8 | Tekke of Karabash Ymer Babes | Tekke of Ymer Baba is located in the vicinity of Prizren, respectively in the village of Leze. There are numerous visitors from all over Kosova. It is mostly visited by people of Gjakova, Prizren and Rahovec.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.151521|20.752878|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |}
==Old houses==
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Number ! Name ! Description ! Location ! Photo |- | 1 | House of Shuaip Pashes | It is located near the Nalet Bridge, built in the 19th century, rebuilt in 2012 after being burned down during the conflict in March 1999.<ref name="ec" /><ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.209424|20.738823|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Shtepia e Shuaip Pashes.JPG|thumb|Shtepia e Shuaip Pashes]] |- | 2 | House of Shehe Zades | It is located in the Saraj Street, and was built at the end of the 18th century. Its architecture features contain Prizren style characteristics.<ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.211347|20.738968|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 3 | House of Shemsidin Kirajtanit | It is close to the Shaip Pasha house and it was built at the beginning of the 19th century.<ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.209059|20.738463|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Shemsidin kirajtanit.JPG|thumb|Shemsidin kirajtanit]] |- | 4 | House of Aqif Celines | It was constructed in the 18th century. It served as a family house. In the 1960s, due to some changes made to it structure, the house lost its originality.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.211816|20.7396|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 5 | House of Sheh Hasanit | This house was built in local folk architecture in the 18th century. It is located in the city center.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.210171|20.740941|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 6 | House of Familjes Grazhda | Oriental home built in the 18th century. It is located in Bujar Godeni Street.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.213|20.739439|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 7 | House of Bajram Pomakut | A traditional Prizren house built in the 18th century.<ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.210481|20.740072|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 8 | House of Abdurahim Myftiut | It is located in Rifat Krasniqi Street, built in the 19th century.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.211737|20.740544|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 9 | House of Ahmet e Shyqeri Suharekes-Rekathatit | This house was built in the year of 1886; besides the divisions the house preserves its originality.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.215217|20.742776|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 10 | House of Ymer Prizrenit | It was built from the president of the Albanian League of Prizren in the period of 1943–1945.<ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.212341|20.743559|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 11 | House of Haxhi Izet Mashkullit | It is supposed that this house is built around the 1800s.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.211156|20.743248|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 12 | House of Ymer Qyse | This house was built in the 19th century.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.211506|20.744718|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 13 | House of Gani Dukagjinit | This house was built in the 19th century and it is considered a cultural monument.<ref name="vc" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.211141|20.743505|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |- | 14 | House of Ismet Sokolit | This house was built in the 19th century, and contains baroque elements.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /><ref name="tek" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.213334|20.741156|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | |}
==Natural monuments==
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Number ! Name ! Description ! Location ! Photo |- | 1 | Plane Tree | It belongs to the 14th century. It can be found in Marash, a region in Prizren.<ref name="exsk" /><ref name="ptv" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.21209|20.745545|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Prizren, 800 let starý platan.jpg|thumb|Prizren, 800 let starý platan]] |- | 2 | Marashi | Marash lies on the east side of Prizren. Its name comes from the Persian language which means “breeze place”. In this complex monumental elements of traditional architecture and that oriental of Prizren are shown.<ref name="exsk" /><ref name="ptv" /><ref name="ec" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.211486|20.746548|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Marashii.JPG|thumb|Marashii]] |- | 3 | The Gorge of Lumbardh | It flows out at a 2360m above sea level, and has a length of 35.5 km. The space in the area of the Lumbardh river during the summer is the most visited place of the city.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.206237|20.756|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Gryka e Lumbardhit 1.JPG|thumb|Gryka e Lumbardhit 1]] |- | 4 | Prevalla | Prevalle is a touristic village which approximately is 30 km away from Prizren. During the summer, people go there to relax and rest, whereas during the winter people visit it for its seasonal recreational sports. It lies 1800m above sea level.<ref name="ptv" /><ref name="mrjk" /><ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.174854|20.962158|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Prevallaa.jpg|thumb|Prevallaa]] |- | 5 | City Park | It is located in the western part of Prizren and it comprises a very large green space. Beside the park flows the city river which grows the values and scenery of the park.<ref name="lb" /><ref name="webi" /> | <small>{{Coord|42.206937|20.726731|format=dms|type:landmark}}</small> | [[File:Parku i Qytetit.JPG|thumb|Parku i Qytetit]] |}

revision.text:
{{Proposed deletion/dated |concern = Non-notable relatively new journal. Not indexed in any ''selective'' databases, no independent sources. Does not meet [[WP:NJournals]] or [[WP:GNG]]. |timestamp = 20181127190011 |help = }} {{Infobox journal | title = Medieval Worlds | image = Logo MEDIEVAL WORLDS.png | image_size = 300px | discipline = [[Medieval Studies]] | peer-reviewed = double-blind peer-reviewed | language = English | editor = [[Walter Pohl]], Andre Gingrich | history = founded 2015 | publisher = Austrian Academy of Sciences Press on behalf of the Institute of Medieval Research at the Academy of Sciences | frequency = biannually | openaccess = open-access | website = https://medieval.vlg.oeaw.ac.at | eISSN = 2412-3196 }} '''Medieval Worlds. Comparative & Interdisciplinary Studies''' is a double-blind [[Peer Review|peer-reviewed]] academic journal in the field of Medieval Studies. It is published semi-annually online and [[Open access|open-access]] by the Austrian Academy of Sciences Press on behalf of the Institute of Medieval Research at the [[Austrian Academy of Sciences]].<ref>[https://www.oeaw.ac.at/en/imafo Institute for Medieval Research]: [https://www.oeaw.ac.at/en/imafo/publications/ejournal E-Journal]; accessed on 20 September 2018.</ref>
The journal’s main scope are interdisciplinary, transcultural and comparative studies of the time period from roughly 400 to 1500 CE, with a focus on Europe, Asia and North Africa.<ref>[https://pf.fwf.ac.at/project_pdfs/pdf_abstracts/oaj52d.pdf FWF Medieval Worlds project abstract]; accessed on 20 September 2018.</ref> The founders and current editors are [[Walter Pohl]] and Andre Gingrich.
''Medieval Worlds'' was established in 2015 with initial funding of the [[Austrian Science Fund|Austrian Science Fund (FWF)]] in an initiative to promote innovative open access journals.<ref>FWF report: [https://www.fwf.ac.at/fileadmin/files/Dokumente/News_Presse/Veranstaltungsrueckblick/2013/11_Anschubfinanzierung_fuer_hochqualitative_OA-Zeitschriften/OAJ_Report_ENG.pdf Initial funding for high quality open access]; accessed on 20 September 2018; [https://pf.fwf.ac.at/en/research-in-practice/project-finder/31661 FWF – research in practice]; accessed on 20 September 2018.</ref>
The journal is indexed in [[Crossref]],<ref>[https://search.crossref.org/?q=%22medieval+worlds%22 Medieval Worlds at Crossref]; accessed on 20 September 2018.</ref> [[DOAJ]],<ref>[https://doaj.org/toc/2412-3196 Medieval Worlds at DOAJ]; accessed on 20 September 2018.</ref> [[ERIH PLUS]]<ref>[https://dbh.nsd.uib.no/publiseringskanaler/erihplus/periodical/info.action?id=487185 Medieval Worlds at ERIH PLUS]; accessed on 20 September 2018.</ref> and EZB.<ref>[http://rzblx1.uni-regensburg.de/ezeit/searchres.phtml?bibid=MFHB&colors=7&lang=en&jq_type1=QS&jq_term1=Medieval+Worlds Medieval Worlds at EZB]; accessed on 20 September 2018.</ref>
== Themes == ''Medieval Worlds'' publishes open issues and themed issues. Among the themes are: * Comparison in Medieval Studies<ref>[http://www.medievalworlds.net/7849-1inhalt Volume 1. 2015] and [http://www.medievalworlds.net/8387-7inhalt Volume 5. 2017]; accessed on 20 September 2018.</ref> * Empires: Elements of Cohesion and Signs of Decay<ref>[http://www.medievalworlds.net/7916-0inhalt Volume 2. 2015]; accessed on 20 September 2018.</ref> * The Genetic Challenge to Medieval History and Archaeology<ref>[http://www.medievalworlds.net/8084-5inhalt Volume 4. 2016]; accessed on 20 September 2018.</ref> * Religious Exemption in Pre-Modern Eurasia, c. 300–1300 CE<ref>[http://www.medievalworlds.net/8243-6inhalt Volume 6. 2017]; accessed on 20 September 2018.</ref> * Medieval Religious Polemic across Genres and Research Cultures<ref>[http://www.medievalworlds.net/8360-0inhalt Volume 7. 2018]; accessed on 20 September 2018.</ref>
== External links == * [https://medieval.vlg.oeaw.ac.at Official Website]

European Summer Time|CEST]] | utc_offset1_DST = +2 <!-- postal codes, area code --> | postal_code_type = Postal code | postal_code = 692 01 | area_code_type = | area_code = | geocode = | iso_code = <!-- website, footnotes --> | website = [http://www.mikulov.cz/ www.mikulov.cz] | footnotes = }} '''Mikulov''' ({{IPA-cs|ˈmɪkulof}}; {{lang-de|Nikolsburg}}; {{lang-yi|ניקאלשבורג}}, ''Nikolshburg'') is a town in the [[Moravia]], [[South Moravian Region]] of the [[Czech Republic]]. [[File:Mikulov-Nicolsburg city seal.jpg|thumb|260px|upright|City Mikulov (Nicolsburg) official Seal, 1810]]
==Geography== The town is part of the historic [[Moravia]] region, located directly on the border with [[Lower Austria]]. In the south, a road border crossing leads to the neighbouring Austrian municipality of [[Drasenhofen]]. The highway is part of the [[European route E461]] and is to be extended as the [[R52 expressway (Czech Republic)|R52 expressway]].
Mikulov is situated between the Pavlovské vrchy hilly area and the edge of the [[Mikulov Highlands]], stretching up to the [[Thaya]] river and the three [[Nové Mlýny reservoirs]]. The [[Pálava Protected Landscape Area]] begins in Mikulov, and so does the [[Moravian Karst]].
==History== After the [[Margraviate of Moravia]] was established, the settlement of ''Nikulsburch'' was first mentioned in a 1249 deed, issued by the [[Přemyslid dynasty|Přemyslid]] margrave [[Ottokar II of Bohemia|Ottokar II]] who granted it, including a castle, and the surrounding area to the [[Duchy of Austria|Austrian]] noble Henry I of [[Princely Family of Liechtenstein|Liechtenstein]]. In 1262 the possession was confirmed by Ottokar, [[List of Bohemian monarchs|Bohemian king]] since 1253. After King [[Rudolf I of Germany]] had defeated Ottokar at the 1278 [[Battle on the Marchfeld]], he then vested Henry II of Liechtenstein with [[market rights]] ''in villa Nicolspurch''. [[German Bohemians|German]] citizens were called in and lived there until their [[Expulsion of Germans from Czechoslovakia|expulsion]] in 1945 according to the [[Beneš decrees]].
===Bohemian Crown=== [[File:Mikulov, zámek.JPG|thumb|left|260px|Mikulov Castle]]
In 1526, the [[Anabaptists|Anabaptist]] leader [[Balthasar Hubmaier]] came from [[Old Swiss Confederacy|Switzerland]] to Nikolsburg, where he was captured and arrested by the forces of the [[House of Habsburg|Habsburg]] king [[Ferdinand I, Holy Roman Emperor|Ferdinand I]] in the following year. The town remained in the Liechtenstein family until 1560, and in 1572 Emperor [[Maximilian II, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian II]] granted the fief to his ambassador to the Spanish court Adam von [[Dietrichstein]]. From 1575 until the 20th century, Nikolsburg remained the proprietary possession of the Dietrichstein noble family and its [[Mensdorff-Pouilly]] successors.
In 1621, during the [[Thirty Years' War]], Cardinal [[Franz von Dietrichstein]] signed the [[Peace of Nikolsburg|Treaty of Nikolsburg]] with the Transylvanian prince [[Gabriel Bethlen]] at [[Mikulov Castle]]. Four years later, Emperor [[Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor|Ferdinand II]] and his [[Aulic titulature|aulic]] council met at the castle, where General [[Albrecht von Wallenstein]] received his commission and was elevated to a [[Duchy of Friedland|Duke of Friedland]]. Franz von Dietrichstein also established the first [[Piarists|Piarist]] college north of the Alps in Nikolsburg.
After a fire damaged the original Nikolsburg Castle in 1719, the Dietrichstein family reconstructed the château to its present appearance. After the [[Austro-Prussian War]], Count [[Alajos Károlyi]] began work on a peace treaty in Nikolsburg that led to the [[Treaty of Prague (1866)|Treaty of Prague]] in 1866.
===Jewish Mikulov=== :{{See also|Familianten}} [[File:V09p305001 Nikolsburg.jpg|260px|thumb|Jewish quarter (1900s)]]
The beginning of the Jewish settlement in Nikolsburg dates as far as 1421, when Jews were expelled from [[Vienna]] and the neighboring province of [[Lower Austria]] by the duke of Austria, [[Albert II of Germany]]. The refugees settled in the town situated close to the Austrian border, some {{convert|85|km|0|abbr=off}} from the [[Austria]]n capital, under the protection of the princes of Liechtenstein, and additional settlers were brought after the expulsions of the Jews from the Moravian royal boroughs by the king [[Ladislaus the Posthumous]] after 1454.<ref name="Nezhodová423">Nezhodová, Soňa. ''The Jewish Mikulov'' (Židovský Mikulov). 1. ed. Brno: Matice moravská, 2006, 423 p. {{ISBN|80-86488-28-4}}</ref>
The settlement grew in importance and in the first half of the 16th century Nikolsburg became the seat of the regional [[rabbi]] of [[Moravia]], thus becoming a cultural centre of Moravian Jewry. The famous rabbi [[Judah Loew ben Bezalel]] (1525 – 1609), who is said to have created the [[golem]] of [[Prague]], officiated here for twenty years as the second regional rabbi between 1553 and 1573.<ref>[http://travel.nytimes.com/2011/09/25/travel/in-the-czech-republic-moravia-and-its-castles.html?pagewanted=all Moravia and its castles]</ref> Cardinal [[Franz von Dietrichstein]], son of Adam von Dietrichstein, was a special protector of the Jews, whose taxes were necessary to finance the Thirty Years' War.<ref name="Jewish Encycl">Jewish Encyclopedia, ''"[http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?letter=N&artid=292 Jewish Nikolsburg]"'', Retrieved 2011-01-30</ref>
In the first half of the 18th century, the congregation in Nikolsburg totalled over 600 families, being the largest Jewish settlement in [[Moravia]]. The census of 1754 decreed by Empress [[Maria Theresa of Austria]] ascertained that there were some 620 families established in Nikolsburg, i.e. the Jewish population of about 3,000 comprised half of the town's inhabitants.<ref name="Nezhodová423"/> Only a small number of Jews could make their living in the town as artisans; the rest had to become merchants. The congregation suffered severely during the [[Silesian wars]] (1740–1742, 1744–1745 and 1756–1763), when they had to furnish the monarchy with their share in the supertaxes exacted by the government of Maria Theresa from the Jews of Moravia.<ref name="Jewish Encycl"/>
Quite a number of Nikolsburg Jews continued to earn their livelihood in Vienna, where they were permitted to stay for some time on special passports. The freedom of residence, which was conceded to the Jews in Austria in 1848, reduced the number of resident Jews in Nikolsburg to less than one-third of the population which it contained at the time of its highest development. In 1904, there were 749 Jewish residents in the city, out of a total population of 8,192.<ref name="Jewish Encycl"/> In 1938, prior to the [[German occupation of Czechoslovakia]], the city population totaled about 8,000 mostly German-speaking inhabitants. Out of these, 472 were Jewish at this time.<ref name="Nezhodová423"/> The Jewish settlement in Nikolsburg ceased to exist during World War II, as only 110 managed to emigrate in time, and 327 of Mikulov's Jews did not survive the [[the Holocaust|Holocaust]].<ref name="Nezhodová423"/>
Following World War II, the town's German population was brutally expelled between 1945-46 by the Czech Communist Government. In 1948, Mikulov's population was around 5,200.
==Demographics== [[File:Mikulov 4826.jpg|260px|thumb|St. Sebastian Chapel on the Holy Hill (''Svatý Kopeček'')]]
{|class="wikitable" align="center" <hiddentext>generated with [[:de:Wikipedia:Helferlein/VBA-Macro for EXCEL tableconversion]] V1.7<\hiddentext> |- align="center" valign="top" |width="64" height="14"|Census year |width="60" rowspan="2"|Population |width="260" colspan="3"|Ethnicity of inhabitants |- align="center" valign="top" |height="14"|year |German |Czechs |other |- align="center" valign="top" |height="13"|1793 |7440 |- |- |- |- align="center" valign="top" |height="13"|1836 |8421 |- |- |- |- align="center" valign="top" |height="13"|1869 |7173 |- |- |- |- align="center" valign="top" |height="13"|1880 |7642 |7447 |144 |61 |- align="center" valign="top" |height="13"|1890 |8210 |8057 |79 |74 |- align="center" valign="top" |height="13"|1900 |8092 |7843 |170 |79 |- align="center" valign="top" |height="13"|1910 |8043 |7787 |189 |67 |- align="center" valign="top" |height="13"|1921 |7699 |6359 |626 |485 |- align="center" valign="top" |height="13"|1930 |7790 |6409 |898 |483 |- align="center" valign="top" |height="14"|1939 |7886 |- |- |- |}<ref>Historický místopis Moravy a Slezska v letech 1848–1960, sv.9. 1984</ref>
== Economy == Mikulov is a centre of [[Czech wine|Czech wine-making]] due to its favorable geographic location and climate, as well as its unique history. Mikulov is not only the centre, but the namesake of, the Moravian wine sub-region ''vinarská podoblast [[Mikulovská wine|Mikulovská]]''.<ref>Wine of the Czech Republic, ''"[http://www.wineofczechrepublic.cz/2-1-2-sub-region-mikulov-en.html Mikulov Wine Region] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719024934/http://www.wineofczechrepublic.cz/2-1-2-sub-region-mikulov-en.html |date=2011-07-19 }}"'', Retrieved 2011-01-30</ref> Twelve registered [[cadastral]] vineyard tracts (Czech: ''trat'') are situated within the Mikulov wine village as defined under the Czech Viticulture Act.<ref>Czech Wine Law, ''"[http://www.vinarskyfond.cz/legislativa/1-vinarska_legislativa_2004.pdf Viticulture Act of 2004] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718190125/http://www.vinarskyfond.cz/legislativa/1-vinarska_legislativa_2004.pdf |date=2011-07-18 }}"'', pg 87-90, Retrieved 2011-01-30</ref> Other significant economic activities in Mikulov are the machine-making and clay industries, as well as oil found at the edge of the [[Viennese Basin]].
==Landmarks== Mikulov's historic buildings, such as Mikulov Castle, and the surrounding wine country draw tourists from the Czech Republic and neighboring countries. Beginning in Mikulov, the 65 kilometer long [[Mikulov Wine Trail]] winds throughout the Mikulov wine region and is a part of [[wine tourism]] in the area. Other noteworthy historic sights are the [[Dietrichstein]] sepulchre, the old [[Jewish quarter (diaspora)|Jewish Quarter]], and the [[Piarist]] College. Several historic churches and a synagogue, built in various architectural styles, are located in Mikulov, including the [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] Church of St. Václav and charnel house, the [[Baroque]] Church of St. John the Baptist, St. Sebastian Chapel on the Holy Hill (''Svatý Kopeček''), the [[neo-Gothic]] Eastern Christian Church of St. Nicolas, and the Altschul Synagogue.
==Notable residents==
===Born in Mikulov=== * [[Johann Ferdinand Hertodt]] (1645–1722), German Moravian physician and writer * [[Moses ben Avraham Avinu]] (?–1733), printer, author, Christian convert to Judaism * [[Jakab Fellner|Jakob Fellner]] (1722–1780), German Moravian Baroque architect * [[Joseph von Sonnenfels]], né Lipmann (1732–1817), Austrian and German Jewish (later Christian) jurist, novelist * [[Anton Joseph Leeb]] (1769–1837), [[Mayor of Vienna]] (1835-1837) * [[Heinrich Landesmann]] (1821–1902), Austrian Jewish poet and philosophical writer * [[Heinrich Auspitz]] (1835–1886), Austrian Jewish dermatologist * [[Elkan Bauer]] (1852–1942), Austrian Jewish composer of popular waltzes * [[Edmund Wengraf]] (1860–1933, Vienna), Austrian jurist, journalist, narrative writer, novelist, essayist, poet, theatre critic * [[Siegfried Altmann]] (1872–1961), Austrian Jewish educator and former Director of Das Israelitisches Blindeninstitut, a Jewish institute for blind children.<ref>Center for Jewish History Digital Collections, ''"[http://digital.cjh.org/R/?func=dbin-jump-full&object_id=431106&local_base=GEN01 Sigfried Altmann Collection]"'', Retrieved 2011-01-30</ref> * [[Moriz Jung]], (1885-1915) Austrian painter and graphic artist, notable for his work for the [[Wiener Werkstätte]] * [[Adolf Schärf]] (1890–1965), Austrian Social Democratic politician and President of Austria (1957-1965) * [[Manfred Ackermann]] (1898–1991), Austrian Social Democratic politician * [[Karel Krautgartner]] (1922–1982), Czech jazz and classical clarinetist, saxophonist, arranger, composer, conductor and teacher
===Resided in Mikulov=== * [[Balthasar Hubmaier]] (1480–1528), Moravian German Anabaptist ([[Schwertler]] [[:de:Schwertler|(de)]]) leader * [[Leonhard Schiemer]] (1500-1528), Austrian Anabaptist writer * [[Adam von Dietrichstein]] (1527–1590), purchaser of the Mikulov estate in 1575 * [[Dietrichstein|Maximilian, Prince of Dietrichstein]] (1596–1655), grandson of Adam von Dietrichstein and owner of the Mikulov estate * [[Aaron Samuel Kaidanover]] (1614-1676), Polish-Lithuanian rabbi * [[Joseph Almosnino]] (1642–1689), Greek-Serbian rabbi * [[Judah he-Hasid (Jerusalem)|Judah he-Hasid]] (1660–1700), Jewish preacher * [[Yaakov Yitzchak of Lublin]] (1745–1815), Polish rabbi * [[Abraham Trebitsch]] (1760–1840), Austrian Jewish scholar * [[Simcha Bunim of Peshischa]] (1765–1827), Polish rabbi * [[Bonifác Buzek]] (1788–1839) [[:de:Bonifác Buzek|(de)]], Moravian priest * [[Abraham Neuda]] (1812–1854), Moravian rabbi * [[Simon Bacher]] (1823–1891), Hungarian Neo-Hebraic poet * [[Meyer Kayserling]] (1829–1905), German rabbi * [[Samuel Baeck]] (1834–1912), German rabbi * [[Karl Borromäus Landsteiner|Karl (Carl) Borromäus Landsteiner]] (''pseudonym: Arthur Landerstein''; 1835, Schloß Stoitzendorf, [[Stoitzendorf]] bei [[Eggenburg]], Lower Austria - 1909, Mikulov), Austrian [[Catholic theologian]], author<ref>aeiou Encyclopedia, ''"[http://www.aeiou.at/aeiou.encyclop./l159167.htm;internal&action=_setlanguage.action?LANGUAGE=en Landsteiner, Karl]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}"'', Retrieved 2011-01-30</ref> * [[Karl Renner]] (1870–1950), Austrian Social Democratic politician, Chancellor of Austria (1918-1920, 1945), President of Austria (1945-1950) * [[Richard Teltscher]] (1888-1974), Austrian Jewish wine-merchant, patron and patriot, founder of the [[Jewish Central Museum for Moravia-Silesia]] in Mikulov
=== Rabbis === {{colbegin}} * [[Judah Löw ben Bezaleel]], the first rabbi of Nikolsburg, chief rabbi of Moravia, officiated in Nikolsburg about 1553–1573 * [[Judah Löb Eilenburg]] (1574–1618) * Gabriel ben Chajjim ben Sinaj (1618–1624) * [[Yom-Ṭob Lipmann Heller]] (1624– ) * [[Pethahiah ben Joseph]] (1631–1637) * Abraham ben Mordechaj Jaffe (1637–1647) * [[Menahem Mendel Krochmal]] (1648–1661) * [[Gershon Ashkenazi]] (1661– ) * [[Aaron Jacob ben Ezekiel]] ( –1671) * [[Judah Löb, son of Menahem Krochmal]] (1672–1684) * [[Eliezer Mendel Fanta]] (1684–1690) * [[David Oppenheim (rabbi)|David Oppenheim]] (1690–1702) * [[Gabriel Eskeles]] (1709–1718) * Bernard Eskeles (1718–1753) * Moses Lwow-Lemburger (1753–1757) * [[Gershon Politz]] (1757–1772) * [[Shmelke of Nikolsburg|Shmuel "S(c)hmelke" (ben Hirsh Halevi) Horowitz of Nikolsburg]] (1772–1778) * [[Gershon Chajes]] (1780–1789) * [[Mordecai Benet]] (1789–1829) * [[Nahum Trebitsch]] (1831–1842) * [[Samson Raphael Hirsch]] (1847–1851) * Hirsch Teltscher (1851–1853) * Isak Weinberger (1853–1855) * [[Solomon Quetsch]] (1855–1856) * [[Mayer Feuchtwang]] (1861–1888) * [[David Feuchtwang]] (1892–1903), also [[IKG Wien|chief rabbi of Vienna]]; Son of Mayer * [[Moritz Levin]] (since 1903–1918) * Alfred Willmann (1919–1938) {{colend}}

{{about|the Mexican American subculture|the Mexican city|Pachuca}} {{More footnotes|date=June 2011}}
[[File:Zoot suits.jpg|thumb|340px|Pachuco culture is associated with the [[zoot suit]] and the idea of making flamboyant appearances in public]]
'''Pachuco''' refers to a [[subculture]] of Chicanos and Mexican-Americans, associated with [[zoot suit]]s, [[street gang]]s, [[nightlife]], and flamboyant public behavior. The idea of the pachuco – a zoot-suited, well-dressed, street-connected flamboyant [[playboy (lifestyle)|playboy]] of Hispanic/Latino heritage – originated in [[El Paso]], [[Texas]], and [[Ciudad Juárez]], [[Mexico]], had moved north, following the line of migration of Mexican railroad workers ("[[traquero]]s") into [[Los Angeles]], where it developed further.
A '''pachuca''' is the female counterpart, often idealized as a beautiful Chicana woman in extravagant evening dress or a female version of the zoot suit, out with a pachuco boyfriend for a night on the town. Pachucas broke [[taboo]]s of their time by wearing men's-style pants sometimes and appearing in public often with their pachuco boyfriends; at the time, a "good woman" was considered to have her place in the home. American women were not encouraged to wear pants, as it was seen as strictly masculine. Because of this, outsiders saw Pachucas as rebellious, tacky, and un-American. This created a larger gap between Mexican-Americans and the rest of the community. However, this was not the intention of the Pachuco/Pachuca style. Pachucas strove to prove that their community fits in to American culture and that they were not of lesser value socially and economically. In order to portray this, they created their suits with luxurious and expensive fabrics. Pachucas made their own clothes and created a space for self expression through fashion.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/272303247|title=The woman in the zoot suit : gender, nationalism, and the cultural politics of memory|last=1969-|first=Ramírez, Catherine Sue,|date=2009|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=9780822342861|location=Durham|oclc=272303247}}</ref> They defied male/female stereotypes and roles in Mexican-American culture in much the same way [[flapper]]s had in European-American culture in the 1920s.
==Origin==
The origin of the term "pachuco" is uncertain, but one theory connects it to the city of El Paso, Texas, which was sometimes referred to as "Chuco Town" or "El Chuco." People migrating to El Paso would say, in Spanish, that they were going "''pa' El Chuco.''" These migrants became known as pachucos.<ref>Zoot Suit Discovery Guide. [http://research.pomona.edu/zootsuit/en/zoot-suit-la/ L.A. in the Zoot Suit Era.] Retrieved 2 June 2013.</ref>
The name "Pachuco" is quite possibly derived from the name of the city of [[Pachuca]], [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]], Mexico. There have long been migrants from Hidalgo state living in Texas.
Another theory says that the word derives from ''[[pocho]]'', a derogatory term for a Mexican born in the United States who has lost touch with the [[Culture of Mexico|Mexican culture]]. The word is also said to mean "punk" or "troublemaker". Yet another theory is put forth by author Laura L. Cummings who postulates a possible indigenous origin of the term. The founder of the "Pachuco" subculture was a Mexican comedian and film actor named [[German Valdés]] better-known by his Artistic name "Tin-Tan". He introduced the Pachuco dress and slang throughout his Golden age-era films.<ref>{{cite web|last=War and Military History Questions|title=Who were the pachucos|url=http://www.wikianswers.com/Q/who_were_the_pachucos|work=Answers|accessdate=7 November 2012}}</ref>
Connections have also been found between "Pachucos" and mixed civilians who lived near the Mexican–American border during the turn of the century, and between "Pachucos" and the poor soldiers who fought in the [[Mexican Revolution]] in the armies of [[Pancho Villa]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/pqp01|title=PACHUCOS|last=ARNOLDO|first=DE LEON,|date=2010-06-15|website=tshaonline.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
[[File:TinTanStatueDF.JPG|thumb|left|Statue of the Mexican actor [[Germán Valdés]] better known as Tin Tan]]
Pachucos called their slang [[Caló (Chicano)|Caló]] (sometimes called "pachuquismo"), a unique [[argot]] that drew on the original Spanish Gypsy Caló, Mexican Spanish, the [[New Mexican Spanish|New Mexican dialect of Spanish]], and American English, employing words and phrases creatively applied. To a large extent, Caló went mainstream and is one of the last surviving vestige of the Pachuco, often used in the lexicon of some urban [[Latino]]s in the United States to this day. The influence of Valdés is responsible for the assimilation of several Caló terms into Mexican slang.
The Mexican [[Nobel Prize in Literature|Nobel laureate]] [[Octavio Paz]] writes in the essay, "The ''Pachuco'' and Other Extremes" that the Pachuco phenomenon paralleled the [[zazou]] subculture in [[World War II]]-era Paris in style of clothing, music favored ([[jazz]], [[Swing (genre)|swing]], and [[jump blues]]), and attitudes. Although there was no known link between the two subcultures, they both are most certainly derivative localized blends of American pop culture in the United States.
Pachuco culture in America was at its height during [[World War II]]. The Wartime Productions Board in 1942 thought it necessary to cut back on fabric consumption, so they enacted regulations on the amount of fabric used for suits. This enactment targeted Pachucos in particular because of the excess fabric used in their zoot suits. Pachucos boldly chose not to follow these regulations, demonstrating rebellious attitudes and pride in their culture. Pachucos continued to flaunt zoot suits, now attained through bootleg tailors. As a result, these flashy zoot suits were seen as unpatriotic by other Americans. This controversial series of events helped shape Pachuco culture, and zoot suits became a symbol of cultural pride among Mexican-Americans. It didn't all end well, however, as this also led to rising tension between Pachucos and other Americans, playing a part in the start of the 1944 [[Zoot Suit Riots]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://research.pomona.edu/zootsuit/en/zoot-suit-la/|title=L.A. in the Zoot Suit Era: Zoot Suit Discovery Guide|last=|first=|date=|website=research.pomona.edu|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The pachuco subculture declined in the 1960s, evolving into the [[Chicano]] style. This style preserved some of the pachuco slang while adding a strong political element characteristic of the late 1960s American life.
In the early 1970s, a recession and the increasingly violent nature of gang life resulted in an abandonment of anything that suggested [[dandyism]]. Accordingly, Mexican-American gangs adopted a uniform of [[T-shirt]]s and [[khaki]]s derived from prison uniforms, and the pachuco style died out. However, the zoot suit remains a popular choice of formal wear for urban and rural Latino youths in heavily ethnic Mexican neighborhoods. It is typically worn at a prom, in weddings, parties or in some cases, at informal Latino university commencement ceremonies.
=== Costa Rica ===
The term "{{wiktspa|pachuco}}" is used in [[Costa Rica]] to define Costa Rican slang. It nevertheless differs from the Mexican slang. In Costa Rica the term "pachuco" refers to someone who has common habits and who is often very rude.<ref>{{cite web|last=Green Energy Network|title=Pachuco|url=http://www.ruralcostarica.com/costa-rican-spanish-word.asp?word=Pachuco|work=Costa Rican Spanish Dictionary|accessdate=5 November 2012}}</ref> In Costa Rica the word pachuco refers to a person who has manners that are socially unacceptable and often uses shocking language when speaking. Pachuco is also a pejorative name given to certain colloquial words and expressions. Some consider pachuco and its pachuquísmos to be Costa Rica's second language.
== Style == Pachuco style was a dominating trend among Mexican-American youth in the 1930s-40s. Pachucos became known for their distinguished look, dialogue, and actions. Pachucos dressed in recognizable [[Zoot suit]]s, and often styled their hair into ducktails. Things like decorative chains and tattoos were also sometimes part of the pachuco look. The unique speech of pachucos was a very important element of their defined style. Consisting of creative phrases and some English words, [[Caló (Chicano)]] was a very popular form of speech among pachucos. Pachucos were seen as gangsters in the eyes of other Americans, because of the activities they participated in. They often carried concealed weapons and were involved in criminal activities such as vandalism and gang-related misdemeanors.<ref>{{Cite web|title = PACHUCOS {{!}} The Handbook of Texas Online{{!}} Texas State Historical Association (TSHA)|url = https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/pqp01|website = tshaonline.org|accessdate = 2015-05-20}}</ref>
==La Pachuca== The "Pachuca," the female counterpart of the Pachuco, had an aesthetic sensibility as strong as the male zoot suiter. The Pachuca's hairstyle tended to be a high "coif" or [[bouffant]], with the hair put up in some way (a more pronounced version of the typical hair style of the time), sometimes using hair grease. Their makeup was heavy, particularly using a red colored lipstick. The preferred colors of clothing were black and gray. Some pachucas wore the traditionally male zoot suit, albeit with modifications to fit the female form. This was very subversive at the time because of long-held [[gender role]]s that dictated how a person should dress. Sometimes, she donned the standard heavy gold pocket chain. Another variation involved a [[sweater]] or [[coat (clothing)|coat]] - often a variant on the male zoot-suit finger-tip jacket - over knee-length [[skirts]], plus [[fishnet stockings]] or [[bobby socks]] and [[platform shoes]].<ref>Ramírez, Catherine S., ''The Woman in the Zoot Suit: Gender, Nationalism, and the Cultural Politics of Memory.'' Durham: Duke University Press, 2009. p. xii [http://www.dukeupress.edu/Catalog/ViewProduct.php?productid=10934]</ref> Extravagant dresses were and are also common among pachucas. Like the entire culture, the fashion aesthetic revolved around the concept of "see and be seen".
This style was associated with gang membership and activity largely due to the [[Zoot Suit Riots]] that took place in [[Southern California]] in 1943. The negative image of the male zoot suiter as a "violent gangster" naturally extended to the Pachuca as well. The promiscuous image came from the Pachuca's high public visibility and patronage of [[nightlife]] with pachucos. This image contrasted with the traditional Latino-American image of [[femininity]] at the time which held that the "good" [[Minority group|minority]] woman stayed in the home.
The Pachuca's challenge to the dominant perception of femininity came during the period between the advent of [[women's suffrage]] in 1920 and the upsurge in [[feminism|feminist]] activism of the 1960s and 1970s.
==See also== {{Portal|Hispanic and Latino Americans}} * [[Zoot Suit Riots]] – a confrontation between pachucos and [[U.S. Navy]] servicemen in Los Angeles during World War II in which unarmed pachucos were brutally beaten and jailed * The opening scenes of the film ''[[American Me]]'' depict confrontations between pachucos and white soldiers during the Zoot Suit Riots * The [[Sleepy Lagoon murder]] was a confrontation between two Los Angeles pachuco gangs that resulted in a crackdown on the culture * [[Cholo]] and [[wikt:vato|Vato]] are terms for modern-day Latino street gangsters, though the association with the zoot suit is no longer present
